    <item>
      <title>Top 10 budget cafes and restaurants in Belfast</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/13/top-10-budget-restaurants-cafes-belfast-northern-ireland</link>
      <description><p>Belfast is bursting with options for good, affordable food – from fish and chips and Tex-Mex to southern Indian and modern British. Updating <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2011/jul/07/belfast-budget-restaurants">our 2011 guide</a>, here are great places to eat for under £10 a head</p><p>Belfast foodies talk about Boojum with almost mystical reverence. That might seem OTT for what, at first glance, looks like a standard Tex-Mex, assembly-line burrito joint, but Boojum is a cut above that. The thick and tender, rope-like tangle of braised, shredded beef in my fat fist of a burrito was excellent. Like everything else in that wrap – from a stridently hot, smoky salsa to the spicy, tomato-based savoury rice – it had a fresh, well-defined flavour. No wonder Boojum is busy.<br><strong>Note: it also has a branch at Botanic Avenue</strong><br>• <em>Dishes from £5.10. 19-27 Chichester Street, 028-9023 0600, </em><a href="http://www.boojummex.com/"><em>boojummex.com</em></a><em>. Open daily 11.30am-10pm</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/13/top-10-budget-restaurants-cafes-belfast-northern-ireland">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Taking children on holiday in term time: the issue that won't go away</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/taking-children-on-holiday-in-term-time-the-issue-that-wont-go-away</link>
      <description><p>One parent is awaiting an appeal over fines for taking his children out of school, and thousands more have already paid £60 penalties. Are families ‘held to ransom’ - and should the government act? </p><p>Ahead of <a href="http://www.jmppartnership.com/school-fines-parents-must-decide/">a high court ruling on the case of a parent who was fined after taking his children on holiday during term time</a>, a travel money provider claims tour operators are “holding parents to ransom” by doubling the costs of family holidays during the summer break. <br tabindex="-1"></p><p>Businessman John Platt will learn tomorrow (13 May) the outcome of his ongoing dispute with Isle of Wight Council, which took him to court in October 2015 after failing to pay a £120 fine for taking his children out of school for a family holiday to Disneyworld Florida. Although <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/education/2015/oct/16/father-overturns-120-fine-taking-daughter-term-time-holiday">the fine was overturned in the magistrates court</a>, the council has appealed to the high court, challenging the decision and seeking clarification on the law.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/taking-children-on-holiday-in-term-time-the-issue-that-wont-go-away">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Oakland city guide: what to see plus the best bars, hotels and restaurants</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/oakland-california-holiday-guide-usa</link>
      <description><p>The city across the bay has shed its inferiority complex and offers plenty of reasons to visit. In fact, you can now skip San Francisco altogether, and fly to Oakland direct from the UK</p><p>Oakland is changing fast. Once known merely as San Francisco’s rough-and-tough neighbour – the birthplace of the Black Panther movement and home of the Hell’s Angels – it is rapidly becoming the most fashionable place in northern California. Those who can’t afford the tech-boom prices across the Bay are making their home in the city and, greeted by an array of new restaurants and bars, a thriving arts scene, and a strong sense of energy and community. Gertrude Stein might have said about her childhood hometown that “There is no there there”, but, these days, Oakland’s residents and visitors are more likely to shout “Come here here!”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/oakland-california-holiday-guide-usa">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>San Francisco on a budget: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/san-francisco-budget-affordable-food-hotel-spa-readers</link>
      <description><p>Despite rampant gentrification, the City by the Bay still has some great affordable experiences, if you know where to look. Readers share their best bargains </p><p>For affordable shelter and transport, just bring a tent and a bike. There’s a <a href="http://www.parksconservancy.org/visit/camp/#Bicentennial">free campsite</a> just a mile away from the northern (Marin county) end of Golden Gate, where a visitor centre offers clean washrooms. From there, cycle across the bridge and catch a <a href="https://www.sfbike.org/resources/bikes-transit/">bike-rack-equipped Muni bus</a>. You can have the run of the whole bus system for a $31 <a href="https://www.sfmta.com/getting-around/transit/fares-passes/visitor-day-passes">three-day bus pass</a>; the bike-and-bus combo gets you anywhere in town.<br><strong>Vbdsun</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/san-francisco-budget-affordable-food-hotel-spa-readers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Museums at Night 2016: the highlights</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/museums-at-night-family-events-uk-heritage-culture</link>
      <description><p>Look at culture in a different light with our pick of 20 of the best events happening all over Britain this weekend as part of the 2016 festival</p><p>Hop on a brightly coloured bus for Newcastle’s culture crawl, which will carry visitors around 70 arts and heritage venues. Events in this 10th outing of the Late Shows include Streetwise Opera in a grade II-listed building, tours of Newcastle Castle, fire-eating in a library and clubbing in underground spaces. Look out for circus taster sessions in a former church, bonsai printmaking at Northern Print and Victorian crime recreations on creepy tours of the Ouseburn district.<br>• <em>13-14 May, many events free, </em><a href="http://thelateshows.org.uk/"><em>thelateshows.org.uk</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/museums-at-night-family-events-uk-heritage-culture">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is this the best pizza in the world?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/11/best-pizza-in-the-world-camapania-naples-italy</link>
      <description><p>Experts writing for a new pizza bible pick a pizzeria in a village near Naples, where chef Franco Pepe tops his handmade dough with local artisanal ingredients</p><p>Billing itself “the experts’ guide to the best pizza places in the world”, <a href="https://bookshop.theguardian.com/catalog/product/view/id/405322/">Where to Eat Pizza</a> features 1,705 pizzerias. Now its compiler,<a href="http://www.youngandfoodish.com/"> Daniel Young</a>, has revealed the restaurant that received the most nominations from the guide’s 1,077 contributors: Pepe in Grani, Caiazzo, Campania.</p><p>Naples may be square one of the pizza world, writes Young, but Caiazzo, a hilltop town some 30 miles north, has emerged as its ground zero or rather its kilometre zero. As a proponent of the Kilometro Zero movement (KM0), Franco Pepe is a local hero, in every sense. He sources mostly from nearby producers. It is only people who travel great distances to Pepe in Grani, his stone-walled pizza palazzo.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/11/best-pizza-in-the-world-camapania-naples-italy">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What a performance: soaking up culture and sunshine at Stockholm’s oldest private theatre</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/11/sodra-teatern-stockholm-theatre-sweden</link>
      <description><p>The historic Södra Teatern, with its magnificent open-air terrace, keeps the locals entertained on balmy summer evenings, says Sarah Dawn Finer, a presenter at the 2016 Eurovision in Stockholm on 14 May</p><p>This time of year, when there’s so much light, all Swedish people want to do is go outside and enjoy it. There’s a place in the south of Stockholm called Södra Teatern that’s set on a hill overlooking the entire city. In the summer, the venue opens this huge terrace, called the Mosebacketerrassen, that seats about 1,500 and has the most spectacular views – you can see the water from almost every angle, which makes for a beautiful backdrop. And because it’s not in the city centre, it’s not at all touristy, just full of locals – apart from the odd visitor who has stumbled across it.</p><p>There’s so much history here. The place was built in 1859 (it’s the city’s oldest private theatre) and it actually comprises several venues, including a jazz club, which hosts brunches and concerts, and a theatre that feels a bit like a smaller version of our opera house. It still has its original box seats, velvet and crystal chandeliers with room for about 450 people, so the theatrical experience is very intimate.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/11/sodra-teatern-stockholm-theatre-sweden">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>France waves goodbye to sleeper trains</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/10/france-waves-goodbye-to-sleeper-trains</link>
      <description><p>SNCF blames the demise of night trains on high costs as it announces plans to end services from Paris </p><p>France is set to say au revoir to the couchette, as the country’s department of transport prepares to withdraw overnight train routes from Paris.</p><p>The French government, which owns the national rail operator SNCF, has said sleeper trains are too expensive to run; it has withdrawn financial support and invited bids to run the services. But unless a proposal is received by 1 July all but three of the dozen or so overnight services will be axed. The only remaining Intercités de Nuit will be from Paris to Briançon, Rodez and Latour-de-Carol, routes deemed socially necessary, according to rail website <a draggable="true" href="http://www.seat61.com/index.html">The Man in Seat Sixty-one</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/10/france-waves-goodbye-to-sleeper-trains">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Stonewall Inn regulars applaud Obama amid monument plans: 'It's about time'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/08/stonewall-inn-customers-barack-obama-monument-riots-1969</link>
      <description><p>With the president reportedly poised to make ‘LGBT ground zero’ a national monument, witnesses and visitors reflect on ‘the night the freaks fought back’ </p><p>In an upstairs room at the Stonewall Inn in New York, drag legend Lady Bunny paused her stream of filthy jokes and Adele parodies just long enough to tell her audience: “This is ground zero for LGBT rights in this country – and the world.”<br></p><p>Most did not need telling. They may have been too young to have taken part in the 1969 uprising that began when lesbian and gay patrons fought back during a police raid, but they were acutely aware of the place in history that the bar enjoys.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/08/stonewall-inn-customers-barack-obama-monument-riots-1969">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A rebirth of ancient skills revitalises a village in Peru’s Sacred Valley</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/09/ccaccaccollo-weaving-market-cusco-peru-sacred-valley</link>
      <description><p>A tourist boom and natural disaster almost led to the extinction of an ancient way of life but, thanks to a women-led initiative, old weaving techniques and economic viability have returned</p><p>Ccaccaccollo village’s weaving market is perched on an emerald-green Andean mountainside, looking out across Peru’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2014/dec/17/top-10-hotels-cusco-sacred-valley-urubamba-peru">Sacred Valley</a>. Inside a straw-roofed hut, two women sit at wooden looms working the foot treadles, transforming the frames into thrusting locomotives. Pumpkin-orange and white fibres intertwine as the shafts shift up and down – clack-clack, clack-clack, clack-clack.</p><p>Next door, bowls bursting with black corn, eucalyptus leaves and pearl white beans line the terracotta shelves. A woman plunges a ball of alpaca fibres into a pot of steaming dye and pulls out the mesh; it drips crimson like the head of a decapitated warrior.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/09/ccaccaccollo-weaving-market-cusco-peru-sacred-valley">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A tale of ice and fire: touring East Iceland</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/08/east-iceland-new-flights-fjords-volcanoes</link>
      <description><p>This summer, new flights from the UK to Egilsstaðir, East Iceland, bring this region of volcanoes and fjords within easy reach</p><p>Denni Karlsson and I are standing by a glacial river as it hammers through a rocky gorge. Beside us is a wooden crate, the size of an old tea chest. It sits on two slender cables that stretch across the torrent 10 metres below.</p><p>“This cableway was the traditional route across the river, part of life in the highlands,” says Denni, who runs horse riding tours of East Iceland from the farmhouse where he now lives with wife Arna Bjarnadóttur. “The last man who farmed here once fell out of it in the middle. He was hauled out unconscious somewhere downstream, but was back at work three days later.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/08/east-iceland-new-flights-fjords-volcanoes">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>A different kind of Chinese takeaway … in Xian’s Muslim food market</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/08/xian-china-muslim-night-food-market</link>
      <description><p>In the former imperial capital in north-west China, local Muslims combine Chinese styles with Middle Eastern spices – to delicious effect</p><p>At dusk, it gets noisy. The kebab sellers start grinding lamb, potatoes are dunked in boiling hot oil and sheets of rice noodles are shaken out, ready to be cut into tubes. Metal carts bump over pavements and wooden mallets strike what looks like nougat, again and again. These are the sounds of the Muslim food market in Xian, in China’s north-western Shaanxi province.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/08/xian-china-muslim-night-food-market">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Beyond the beach: Bulgaria’s hidden treasures</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/08/bulgaria-mountains-and-monasteries-rural-holidays</link>
      <description><p>Mountains, monasteries and markets… there’s much more to Bulgaria than a cheap beach break, says Kate Eshelby</p><p>I’m laden with juicy fat cherries, freshly plucked from the tree. The sun shines and we’re picnicking among spangles of wild flowers and long grasses. A track steers back to the wood-beamed house where we are staying, past mud-and-timber houses tilting back into the earth.</p><p>I’m with my husband Mark and two children in a tiny hillside hamlet called Baba Stana, close to the village of Oreshak, in the heart of central Bulgaria’s Balkan mountains. It’s peaceful and bucolic, and far from the cheap-and-cheerful skiing or beach packages Bulgaria is most known for.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/08/bulgaria-mountains-and-monasteries-rural-holidays">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Aruba's wild side</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/07/aruba-wild-side-direct-flights-caribbean-holiday</link>
      <description><p>There’s much more to the Caribbean island of Aruba than its gorgeous white sands (and all-inclusives). Its untamed side offers rugged landscapes and remote beaches – and there are now direct flights from the UK</p><p>Twenty-four hours into my visit to Aruba, a tiny island 15 miles off the tip of Venezuela, I’ve slipped into an easy routine. It starts with fresh juice on the balcony of my <em>casita</em> at Boardwalk Aruba, on the island’s northern tip. I watch the bright green lizards soaking up the first rays of sun before cycling to nearby <a href="http://www.dushibagelsandburgers.com/home">Dushi Bagels</a>, a family-run cafe whose walls heave with paintings by local artists and shade is provided by palm trees wrapped in colourful crochet.</p><p>This month, Thomson Airways added direct flights to Aruba from Manchester, and Virgin Holidays has just added the island to its portfolio. But growing numbers are discovering that Aruba isn’t just for those in search of fly-and-flop beach holidays: in 2015 there was a 12% increase in UK visitors.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/07/aruba-wild-side-direct-flights-caribbean-holiday">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>More than 1,000 cabin crew have begun voting in ballot for industrial action in dispute over rest breaks</p><p>Thomas Cook cabin crew are voting on possible strike action during the May half-term school holiday in a dispute over health and safety after changes to their rest breaks. </p><p>Cabin crew will be allowed one 20-minute break over 12 hours, according to Unite, Britain’s largest union, and more than 1,000 cabin crew have begun voting in a ballot for industrial action. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/06/thomas-cook-cabin-crew-strike-threat-may-half-term-school-holiday">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Seaside style: relaxing at Sri Lanka’s coolest new surf shack</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/05/the-shack-cafe-surfing-dewata-beach-sri-lanka</link>
      <description><p>‘Dirty little beach’ is an odd slogan for a surfing cafe, but The Shack has become a clear favourite on Dewata beach, near Galle</p><p>“Here,” said the tuk-tuk driver, and we clambered out onto a particularly scruffy stretch of the busy Matara road, the coastal drag running south of Galle, southern Sri Lanka. There was a moment of confusion before I spotted the bright yellow sign for The Shack among the hardware stores and caught a glimpse of sand and sea through its open door. </p><p>In the last couple of years Dewata beach, a wide sandy bay lined with dilapidated buildings, has become an unlikely <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/23/sri-lanka-surfing-yoga-retreat">surfing hotspot</a> among local expat families, weekenders from Colombo and in-the-know tourists, thanks to its small, consistent waves; and The Shack, which opened in January 2016, is their new hangout.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/05/the-shack-cafe-surfing-dewata-beach-sri-lanka">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 back-to-nature cottages and campsites in Wales</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/04/top-10-back-to-nature-cottages-campsites-wales</link>
      <description><p>Step out of these Welsh holiday homes and campsites into the great outdoors –with walking, cycling, kayaking or surfing all on the doorstep or nearby </p><p>The perfect mix of rustic escapism and urban comfort, this pretty stone cottage sits between the Wye valley and the Forest of Dean, with access to great walking straight from the door, as well as kayaking and mountain biking. Inside the two-bedroom retreat, stone floors, stripped wooden beams and a 19th-century range are brought up to date by underfloor heating, designer bathrooms and an uncluttered aesthetic. Despite the clean lines, it’s dog-friendly and great for families with young children, with a cot, high-chair and stair-gate provided, a fenced garden for running around in (or barbecuing) and a boot room with washing machine, tumble dryer and space for storing bikes.<br>• <em>From £503 for three nights, sleeps 4/5, </em><a href="https://www.sugarandloaf.com/cottages/fox-and-hounds-cottage?month=1972-07&amp;range="><em>sugarandloaf.com</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/04/top-10-back-to-nature-cottages-campsites-wales">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mexico City’s grandest neighbourhood is back in vogue</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/03/mexico-city-colonia-juarez-regeneration-bars-restaurants</link>
      <description><p>The formerly wealthy Colonia Juárez, close to Mexico City’s historic centre, is getting its groove back, with new restaurants, bars and art galleries</p><p>It’s morning in Mexico City, and the traffic on Avenida Reforma, the city’s central artery, is in full flow, interspersed only by <em>tamale </em>carts dashing madly into the path of oncoming cars. A block away, its entrance guarded by two of the city’s landmark skyscrapers, Torre Mayor and Torre Bancomer, is Colonia Juárez, once the <em>grande dame</em> of Mexico City neighbourhoods, and now making a long-awaited comeback. </p><p>A few kilometres west of the historic centre, Juárez used to be the grandest <em>colonia </em>in the city<em>.</em> Local architect Rutilo Rojas says: “At the tail end of the <em>porfiriato</em> [when Porfirio Díaz ruled Mexico, 1876-1911], wealthy families built enormous French-influenced mansions in Juárez, and lived there until the mid-century’s new urban developments began. Many demolished their mansions and replaced them with office blocks, which were easier to rent out.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/03/mexico-city-colonia-juarez-regeneration-bars-restaurants">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sailing in Cornwall: learn the ropes – in a weekend</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/01/sailing-holiday-weekend-cornwall</link>
      <description><p>Despite a battering by a spring storm, this novice sailor gets stuck right in <br> with the crewing of a century-old, two-masted wooden ketch on a two-day trip off the Cornish coast</p><p>Our first few hours aboard Bessie Ellen were hands-on. As storm Katie tightened her grip on the Cornish coast, the 112-year-old sailing ship was ploughing through high winds, and minutes after casting off we were pulling up sails, tacking and steering. Owner and skipper Nikki Alford commanded respect while instilling a sense of fun, and within half an hour had turned us eight strangers into a crew capable of steering a two-masted wooden ship through a storm. In a couple of hours I’d hauled ropes with Anton, who’s in his late 70s, and hoisted sails with a father and son from Exeter. We learned how to tack and could soon just about name all the sails.</p><p>I had joined the tall ship at Fowey for a two-night taster weekend. Apart from taking the Seacat from Liverpool to Dublin when I was eight, I had never sailed before. We were a mixed bunch, ranging from competent sailors to, well, me. Either way, everyone had a role. “I like to get everyone involved,” said Nikki. “I want people to feel they’re part of a crew – and learn a thing or two.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/01/sailing-holiday-weekend-cornwall">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The best mutton chop in Kolkata</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/01/kolkata-india-mutton-chop-street-food</link>
      <description><p>This street food favourite is so popular it can be found at vendors across the Indian city, but Harneet Baweja, founder of Gunpowder in east London, has his favourite spots</p><p>Kolkata is a cultural and intellectual hub, buzzing with Ambassador taxis, the hum of street food vendors offering piping hot food and the sound of customers crunching on <em>pani puri</em>, hollow fried crisp balls filled with a spicy liquor (<em>pani</em>), tamarind chutney, chilli, potato, onion and chickpeas. There is an abundance of street food available in Kolkata, especially at hubs such as Dacres Lane. Here my wife and I have tried every snack you can think of, from traditional Bengali <em>ghugni</em> (dried white peas mixed with tamarind, chillies and jaggery) to Bengal’s take on Chinese chow mien.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/nov/03/10-best-restaurants-street-food-snacks-goa-india">10 of the best restaurants and street food snacks in Goa</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/01/kolkata-india-mutton-chop-street-food">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Your own Motorcycle Diaries: touring Cuba with Che Guevara’s son</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/30/ernesto-guevara-motorbike-tours-cuba</link>
      <description><p>Explore both well-trodden and lesser-known parts of Cuba with Ernesto Guevara on a gleaming Harley Davidson. Plus five more Cuban tours</p><p>It’s a sunny morning in Trinidad, Cuba, and in front of a row of brightly painted colonial houses, a vintage Harley Davidson is attracting admiring glances. But a newer Harley parked behind it, outside a guesthouse, probably has a more interesting story: it belongs to Ernesto Guevara, son of revolutionary hero Che.</p><p>Ernesto runs motorbike tours of Cuba and today, before setting off for the mountains and beach, he’s having breakfast in the guesthouse courtyard with his group. Wearing a black Harley T-shirt and wristband, he looks younger than his 51 years.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/30/ernesto-guevara-motorbike-tours-cuba">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Tips for independent travellers to Cuba</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/30/cuba-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>Travelling in Cuba is unique – in both a good and infuriating way. Here are a few tips on making it easier</p><p>If you’re travelling independently, don’t even think about arriving in Cuba without your first few nights (or entire holiday if you want a smooth ride) booked at Cuba’s B&amp;Bs (<em>casas particulares</em>) or hotels. The <a href="http://www.cubatravelnetwork.com/">Cuba Travel Network</a> website offers live availability for hotels. For B&amp;Bs use <a href="http://www.hostelsclub.com/">hostelsclub.com</a>, <a href="http://cubacasas.net/">cubacasas.net</a>, <a href="https://www.airbnb.co.uk/s/Cuba?s_tag=HCXpe3Fx">airbnb.com</a>, and guidebook recommendations, or try <a href="https://www.homestay.com/cuba">homestay.com</a> for stays with locals.</p><p>Online bookings for the country’s only scheduled tourist coach service, <a href="http://www.viazul.com/">Víazul</a>, can only be made seven days in advance, so you need to plan ahead. You must print your reservation to receive your ticket at the bus station. Many routes are oversubscribed. If your travel plans aren’t fixed, turn up early at the station and join the queue.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/30/cuba-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Five of the best scenic bike rides in Devon</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/27/five-best-scenic-bike-rides-devon-dartmoor-exmoor-england</link>
      <description><p>These cycle routes, featuring Dartmoor and Exmoor, make the most of Devon’s dramatic countryside – plus there’s a pub stop recommended for each one, too<br><br>• <strong>Tell us about your favourite Devon cycle route in the comments below </strong></p><p><strong>Distance</strong> 32 miles/51km<br><strong>Total climbing</strong> 2,546ft/776m<br><em>Moderate. Mostly on traffic-free former railway path with a loop on hilly lanes<br></em><strong>Start/finish</strong> Okehampton<br>The 11-mile <a href="http://www.visitdartmoor.co.uk/things-to-do/the-granite-way-cycle-route-p250623">Granite Way</a> from Okehampton to Lydford is a spectacular rails-to-trails cycleway that passes within three miles of High Willhays, the highest point in Dartmoor and the highest place in England south of the Peak District. There are fine views not least from its magnificent Victorian viaducts. This ride adds to the pleasures of the Granite Way with a loop of lovely (and hilly) lanes taking in Brent Tor, one of western Dartmoor’s most iconic landmarks. A mile out of Okehampton is the Meldon Viaduct, a gently curved, tottering Victorian lattice of wrought and cast iron 150ft above the West Okement river. A few miles on is Lake Viaduct with its stately granite arches. The rail trail ends at Lydford, a pretty Dartmoor village that was an important seat of power in Saxon and Norman times. Its castle and fortifications are free to explore while <a href="http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/lydford-gorge">Lydford Gorge</a>, which has a 30m-high waterfall, is free for National Trust members. It’s a steady climb up to Brent Tor, an extinct volcano topped by a 14th-century chapel. A descent through Chillaton leads to a bridge over the river Lyd. The last big climb is onto Galford Down, from where there are fine views to Dartmoor’s highest tors. The return journey follows the Granite Way back to Okehampton.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/27/five-best-scenic-bike-rides-devon-dartmoor-exmoor-england">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/devon">Devon holidays</category>

    <item>
      <title>What makes a great walk?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/what-makes-a-great-walk-walking-holidays</link>
      <description><p>Shanks’s pony is still the best way to explore our planet’s natural beauty. Kevin Rushby looks at what makes a great hike, and the ‘walking revolution’ of recent decades<br><strong>More on walks: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/10-best-walks-holidays-in-europe">Europe</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/british-walks-uk-family-long-distance-paths-trails">UK</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/top-long-distance-walks-worldwide">epic</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/gallery/2016/apr/23/boots-kit-for-walkers-in-pictures">best kit</a></strong></p><p>I hate walking. I won’t do it. I am not going any further. Unorthodox as it may seem, as an introduction to a celebration of great walks, I need to put those words down and look at them. They are certainly the words every parent fears. The words I inflicted, as a nine-year-old on my dad on Snowdon, were later echoed by my own children. They are uttered, or just thought, at the crucial moment in many a great walk, usually when a corner is turned and the true dimensions of the landscape open up and show a narrow stony path, winding onwards for long miles, always upwards, to a goal that is impossibly distant and probably wreathed in ominous black clouds. The view up Langdale towards Lakeland’s Scafell massif often conforms to this pattern. Children do us a service in voicing such feelings; we adults often ignore them, or soldier onwards, never appreciating that this is all part of the drama.</p><p>You see I do believe that great walks are like great dramas. Act One is the optimistic practicalities: the picnic packing, the maps and checklists, the jokes and the laughter. You set off with fresh faces and jollity. But then, just as the effort starts to bite, comes that moment. I suppose the ancient Greeks had a word for it. Suddenly there is the threat of tragedy in the air, or at least the disappointment of turning back. But something keeps you going: it could be the promise of lunch, or a shaft of sunlight that warms your back. And, by the simple formula of putting one foot in front of the other, those long upward miles fall behind. Then the summit is in sight, the views become magnificent and soggy cheese sandwiches taste amazing. Triumph is felt.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/what-makes-a-great-walk-walking-holidays">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/walkingholidays">Walking holidays</category>

    <item>
      <title>10 great walking holidays in Europe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/10-best-walks-holidays-in-europe</link>
      <description><p>We round up some of the best guided and self-guided walks that explore the continent’s high peaks, deep fjords and rare wildlife<br><strong>More great walks: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/british-walks-uk-family-long-distance-paths-trails">UK</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/top-long-distance-walks-worldwide">epic</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/gallery/2016/apr/23/boots-kit-for-walkers-in-pictures">best kit</a></strong></p><p>Some parts of Iceland are well-trodden, but the east remains a vast wilderness of ice and fire. This eight-day adventure takes in an impressive array of what the island offers: you start with a warm-up walk to Strútsfoss, a thunderous 100m waterfall, then explore deeper into the country with an ascent of 1,833m Snæfell, a snow-capped peak that gives extensive panoramas of Vatnajökull, Iceland’s massive ice cap, and Bárðarbunga, a volcano that erupted in 2014 and continues to grumble. You might spot reindeer and pink-footed geese. A foray down the Jokulsa gorge is followed by three days of coastal and ridge walks that include areas deeply embedded in Iceland’s mythology such as Alfaborg, home to the elves. These may only be spotted, however, with the assistance of <em>brennivín</em>, Icelandic potato schnapps seasoned with caraway.<br>• <em>Eight-day guided trip with </em><a href="https://www.discover-the-world.co.uk/destinations/iceland-holidays/hiking-in-east-iceland"><em>Discover the World</em></a><em> departs 13 July and 27 July, from £1,833 full board including flights (from Gatwick or £300 credit) </em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/23/10-best-walks-holidays-in-europe">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>10 of the best B&Bs in Lima, Peru</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/02/top-10-bed-and-breakfast-lima-peru</link>
      <description><p>Once just a stop on the way to Machu Picchu, Peru’s capital is now a hot destination in its own right – and the first direct flights from the UK, <a href="http://www.britishairways.com/en-gb/destinations/lima-peru/flights-to-lima-peru?clickpage=flights-and-holidays--flights--new-routes&amp;kmtag=c&amp;ban=%7c%7cDHC%7c24%7cCTA1%7c%7c%7c%7c%7c%7c%7c%7c%7cL2%7c%7c%7c%7c%7c%7c%7c">with BA from 4 May</a>, will make it even easier to reach</p><p>Mixing minimalism with eclectic finds, this four-room B&amp;B in lively Miraflores is a showcase for co-owner Humberto’s eye-catching collection of Andean artworks. These, along with vintage prints of Inca ruins, adorn the bright white walls. Two rooms have claw-foot baths, the other two have balconies overlooking the courtyard and all come with kingsize beds and personal touches such as vases of fresh flowers. The garage has been turned into a colourful breakfast room where an antique door serves as the table – choices range from spinach pancakes to homemade granola. Then you can borrow one of the vintage bikes to explore on.<br tabindex="-1">• <em>Doubles from $125 B&amp;B, +51 1 396 2740, </em><em tabindex="-1"><a draggable="true" href="http://www.hoteldeautor.com/">hoteldeautor.com</a></em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/02/top-10-bed-and-breakfast-lima-peru">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mi casa es tu casa: Cuba’s best hotels, B&Bs and farmstays</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/30/cuba-stays-casa-particulares-bed-breakfast-homestay-havana-trinidad</link>
      <description><p>The ink was barely dry on measures easing the US embargo before the big hotel brands began plotting their moves. But don’t worry, there are more genuinely Cuban places to stay than ever</p><p>With the relaxation of certain parts of the US’s trade embargo, American hotels are moving into Cuba for the first time since 1959. Starwood has agreed a deal to rebrand two hotels in Havana, and signed a letter of intent to convert a third; Marriott has received the green light from the US government to begin operations on the island; booking.com will launch Cuba hotels soon; and AirBnB has just announced that the whole world – not just Americans – can now book its Cuba listings. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/30/cuba-stays-casa-particulares-bed-breakfast-homestay-havana-trinidad">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/cuba">Cuba holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/northandcentralamerica">North and Central America holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/travel">Travel</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/bed-and-breakfasts">Bed and breakfasts</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/hotels">Hotels</category>

    <item>
      <title>Holiday guide to Costa Rica: beaches and adventures, plus hotels and restaurants</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/nov/28/costa-rica-holiday-guide-beaches-hotels</link>
      <description><p>This small country is perhaps the best in Latin America for a tropical adventure, thanks to its misty jungles, incredible wildlife, active volcanoes and glorious deserted beaches<br>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/nov/25/costa-rica-readers-central-america-rainforest"><strong>Readers’ tips on where to go in Costa Rica</strong></a></p><p>The essential itinerary for Costa Rica was defined long ago: Manuel Antonio for the beach, Monteverde for cloud forest, Tortuguero for turtles, and Arenal volcano for outdoor adventure. Add in the area of sandy beachfront in Guanacaste that has also been set aside for large hotels and you have all the elements of most package tours to the country.</p><p>But the true beauty of Costa Rica lies in its smaller, emptier spaces. And though there is plenty of adventure on offer (when they say you can zipline from one end of the country to the other, they’re only half joking), it’s the V-formation of pelicans flying over your hammock, lightning over a silver sea, pink orchids against turquoise houses, a passing cowboy with silver stirrups, the white sand and deep blue sea that stay in the memory – along with the state of the roads.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/nov/28/costa-rica-holiday-guide-beaches-hotels">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Amsterdam Noord: the best galleries, bars, restaurants and hotels</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/12/amsterdam-noord-adam-toren-bars-restaurants-clubs</link>
      <description><p>A’DAM Toren, a new multi-venue tower, is the latest addition to Amsterdam’s creative hub, where a former shipyard and warehouses have been transformed into the city’s coolest waterfront district</p><p>The landmark tower, Toren Overhoeks, will reopen in early May as A’DAM Toren – Amsterdam Dance And Music. The former home of Shell, the 22-storey waterfront tower will have clubs, bars, cafes, a revolving restaurant, a 360-degree observation deck, offices and a 110-room hotel, Sir Adam, run by the people behind luxury boutique hotel <a href="http://www.siralberthotel.com/">Sir Albert</a>, also in Amsterdam. The trio at the helm of A’DAM Toren – Sander Groet, Duncan Stutterheim and Hans Brouwer – are well known in the Dutch music and events scene and a host of companies in the creative industry have signed up for the office space. Expect a few quirks: a giant swing hanging from the top-floor observation deck, clubs on both the top and bottom floors, graffiti in the car park and the two-floor “Loft”, with seven-metre-high windows, a bar and DJ booth, which promises to be the hippest hotel suite in the city.<br>• <em>Opens May 2016, </em><a href="http://adamtoren.nl/"><em>adamtoren.nl</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/12/amsterdam-noord-adam-toren-bars-restaurants-clubs">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Indonesia beginners’ guide: Bali, Lombok, Java and Flores</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/09/indonesia-holiday-guide-bali-lombok-java-flores</link>
      <description><p>This vast country’s 17,000 islands would take years to explore. As a new direct flight from the UK to Indonesia launches, we pick what to do and see plus the best hotels, food and drink in four popular destinations</p><p>The world’s largest island nation, Indonesia comprises about 17,000 islands sprawling over almost two million square kilometres either side of the equator. It includes half of the world’s second-largest island, New Guinea, and most of the world’s third-largest, Borneo, as well as rugged Sumatra and busy Java. Its distinctive wildlife includes pygmy elephants, tree kangaroos and the Komodo dragon; its dramatic landscape embraces ancient rice terraces, untamed jungle, islands with pristine coral fringed by white sands and lava-spewing volcanoes. And now that national carrier Garuda has launched the first direct flights from the UK to Jakarta, the nation’s capital and transport hub, Britons are just two flights away from pretty much anywhere in the archipelago.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/09/indonesia-holiday-guide-bali-lombok-java-flores">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ljubljana, Slovenia: what to see plus the best hotels, bars and restaurants</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/02/ljubljana-slovenia-guide-hotels-bars-restaurants-city-break</link>
      <description><p>Slovenia’s – and now Europe’s – green capital is a laid-back charmer of a city. Easily walkable, it boasts striking architecture and a vibrant outdoor eating and drinking culture</p><p>As capital of one of Europe’s most forested countries, it’s perhaps fitting that Ljubljana is this year’s European Green Capital. A city of just 300,000 inhabitants, Ljubljana has often been ahead of the game when it comes to green initiatives – from the introduction of a sophisticated waste management system (Ljubljana was the first EU capital to adopt a zero-waste programme) and the creation of new green spaces from degraded urban land, to electrically powered golf buggy-type vehicles (<a href="http://www.greenljubljana.com/funfacts/kavalir"><em>kavalirs</em></a>) offering free transport around the old town, which is otherwise closed to traffic. Official <a href="http://greenljubljana.com/">Green Capital celebrations</a> kicked off last month, but there are numerous events taking place throughout the year.</p><p>The city oozes charm, a delightful confection of Baroque and Habsburg inspired-architecture, richly painted churches, abundant greenery and engaging riverside cafes. Moreover, its location, at the heart of this tiny, but astonishingly diverse country, means it’s no more than a couple of hours away from anywhere, be it the imperious limestone mountains and glacial lakes of the Julian Alps, the magical subterranean world of the Karst region, historic coastal towns or the lush vineyards in its hinterland.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/02/ljubljana-slovenia-guide-hotels-bars-restaurants-city-break">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Chiang Mai, Thailand, guide: what to do, plus the best hotels and restaurants</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/26/chiang-mai-guide-thailand-activities-hotels-restaurants-bars</link>
      <description><p>Northern Thailand’s largest city has struck a fine balance between the traditional and the contemporary, and offers unique cuisine, affordable stays and must-do treks<br>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/24/thai-street-food-chiang-mai-tour-thailand"><strong>Chiang Mai food paradise: ‘the best I’ve ever eaten’</strong></a></p><p>With long, leafy boulevards, Chiang Mai presents an alluring alternative to the Thai capital, Bangkok. Instead of traffic-choked urban sprawl, travellers find a picturesque downtown easily navigated on foot, where the air is clean and the climate mercifully cool. A short bike or scooter ride out of the town leads to a densely rainforested countryside interspersed with waterfalls. Since the local airport received an upgrade in 2014, more regional flights have been heading to this serene city, making it cheaper and easier to reach.</p><p>The old town, inside its moat, is an extraordinary vision. Here amid the 30-odd temple spires, barefoot monks in flame-coloured robes collect alms in the morning and street vendors sell their wares by night.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/26/chiang-mai-guide-thailand-activities-hotels-restaurants-bars">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Dublin city guide: what to see, plus the best hotels, bars and restaurants</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/19/dublin-city-guide-best-pubs-restaurants-hotels</link>
      <description><p>As the city marks the centenary of the Easter Rising, our writer finds its free-thinking spirit alive at offbeat museums, bars, restaurants and in its architecture</p><p>This is a big year for Ireland and its capital. The country is preparing to mark the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/25/easter-rising-tour-dublin-google-maps-colin-farrell">centenary of the Easter Rising</a>, a rebellion that culminated in Irish independence, and Dublin is set to be the centre of the commemoration. There have been debates over how 1916 should be celebrated, but O’Connell Street’s neoclassical General Post Office, the de facto headquarters of the insurrection, will be at the centre of things, <a href="http://www.gpowitnesshistory.ie/">hosting an immersive exhibition</a>, from 29 March.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/19/dublin-city-guide-best-pubs-restaurants-hotels">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/dublin">Dublin holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/city-breaks">City breaks</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/travel">Travel</category>

    <item>
      <title>Edinburgh city guide: what to see plus the best hotels, bars and restaurants</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/04/edinburgh-guide-hotels-restaurants-sights-bars</link>
      <description><p>Dodge the tartan and tour groups with Vonny Moyes’s guide to Edinburgh’s contemporary culture, bars brimming with personality, and great-value places to eat and stay</p><p>Edinburgh’s dirtiest trick is hiding in plain sight. Sold a 2D iteration of Braveheart, bagpipes and festivals, tourists cling to trademark attractions that have steep prices and no soul. When festival revellers swell the population in August, most of them head indoors, trading the capital’s spoils for darkened rooms. But there’s much to discover beyond the summer festivals and the shortbread Scottishness sold in the tourist traps.</p><p>Venture out from the Royal Mile and you’ll find weathered stones and tall spires punctuated with green giants. In an afternoon, you can conquer an ancient volcano or scale an abandoned acropolis without leaving the centre.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/04/edinburgh-guide-hotels-restaurants-sights-bars">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>10 of the best Russia holiday destinations – beyond Moscow and St Petersburg</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/15/10-best-russia-holiday-destinations-beyond-moscow-st-petersburg</link>
      <description><p>Majestic lakes, mountains, history and even ecotourism resorts, opt for Russia’s lesser-known cities and nature parks and there’s enough to keep you exploring for weeks. Share your Russia tips in the comments below</p><p><strong>Why go?</strong><br>Karelia, a republic in north-west Russia, is known as one the country’s most beautiful places. The nature here is breathtaking and more Finnish than Russian, with lakes, waterfalls and trees growing on giant rocks. Ruskeala is a village close to Sortavala, one of the region’s bigger towns. The main interest here is Ruskeala mountain park, with a marble canyon that is now a lake with crystal clear water, and another underground lake. You can rent boats, go diving, or hike. In summer there are light shows on the lake.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/15/10-best-russia-holiday-destinations-beyond-moscow-st-petersburg">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>10 of the best beachside stays in tropical Asia</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/09/asia-tropical-beach-bungalows</link>
      <description><p>These great value bungalows and cabanas make superb bases from which to explore the exotic beaches and aquatic riches of Asia’s equatorial shores</p><p>Not to be confused with the more expensive Coral View Villas down the road, this Balinese-owned place sits right on a little strip of calm, safe beach in serene Jemeluk, Amed. There’s good snorkelling, including an underwater temple, just off shore, and a relaxed, vibe that’s perfect for children. The two elegant dark wood beachfront “villas”, with cute front gardens and galleried attic bedrooms, make an excellent family choice. Parents of young children will appreciate the fridge and kettle, while the draped four poster, pleasant bathrooms and frangipani flowers add style. <br>• <em>From £41 B&amp;B for up to four, </em><em><a href="http://balivillacoral.com/">balivillacoral.com</a><br></em><strong>Theodora Sutcliffe</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/09/asia-tropical-beach-bungalows">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Zurich city guide: what to see, plus the best restaurants, bars and hotels</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/06/zurich-city-guide-switzerland-hotels-bars-restaurants</link>
      <description><p>Yes, it’s big on banking and watches but don’t imagine the Swiss city is entirely straitlaced – this year it’s going gaga over Dada for starters</p><p>Although it’s routinely placed at the top of lifestyle rankings, Zurich is rarely, if ever, rated as one of Europe’s cultural capitals. There’s a perception that it’s a bankers’ city – a Swiss Square Mile without any West End to escape into. While it is true that high salaries and a strong currency mean Switzerland’s biggest city is expensive for visitors, with some planning, and a focus on culture instead of cuisine, it makes for an enjoyable break, whether or not it is made part of a skiing holiday.</p><p>The city boasts cultural big-hitters including the Kunsthaus (see below), one of Europe’s great modern art museums, and Museum Haus Konstruktiv (<a href="http://hauskonstruktiv.ch/">hauskonstruktiv.ch</a>), which showcases “concrete, constructive and conceptual art” in a former electricity substation. <a href="https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/attractions/zurich-west">Zurich-West</a>, a former industrial district, is a hub for contemporary art, design, food and architecture. The whole city is relatively car-free and bike-friendly.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/06/zurich-city-guide-switzerland-hotels-bars-restaurants">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>10 of the best jazz clubs in Europe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/02/10-best-jazz-clubs-europe-paris-berlin-madrid-prague</link>
      <description><p>Get in the groove at swingin’ jazz clubs from Berlin and Brighton to Paris and Madrid. Whether you want laid-back or out-there, you will find good vibes</p><p>Europe’s westernmost capital city has one of Europe’s oldest jazz clubs: Hot Clube, founded in 1948, has hosted legends such as Count Basie, Dizzy Gillespie, Sarah Vaughan and Dexter Gordon. And on 22 and 24 February this 140-capacity club will host another elder statesman of jazz: 89-year-old <a href="http://loudonaldson.com/">Lou Donaldson</a>, a soulful alto sax player influenced by Charlie Parker. So … old, old, old. Not so. Jazz reinvents itself and so has Hot Clube – literally, after its original premises went up in smoke in 2009. Happily, it reopened three years later two doors away thanks to the support of Lisbon residents and businesses and the work of the association that founded it. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/02/10-best-jazz-clubs-europe-paris-berlin-madrid-prague">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Great Barrier Reef, Queensland: where to dive, snorkel and stay</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/30/great-barrier-reef-australia-holiday-guide</link>
      <description><p>As <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/21/david-attenborough-great-barrier-reef-australia">David Attenborough’s</a> new three-part reef documentary begins, here’s our guide to exploring the world’s largest living structure and its Australian coast, from scuba diving trips to rainforest excursions – plus the best places to stay</p><p>The <a href="http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/154">Unesco world heritage-listed</a> natural wonder is a ribbon of blinding blues and greens, a constellation of islands and reefs, running parallel with the Queensland shoreline from the tip of Cape York in the north 1,600 miles south to Bundaberg. At the reef’s southernmost end are Lady Elliot and Heron islands, two stars of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/21/david-attenborough-great-barrier-reef-australia">David Attenborough’s new three-hour</a><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/21/david-attenborough-great-barrier-reef-australia"> documentary</a> (screening at 9pm on 30 December, BBC1); heading north, Airlie Beach, Townsville and Cairns are popular starting points for reef explorations.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/30/great-barrier-reef-australia-holiday-guide">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Where to go on holiday in 2016</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/01/2016-holiday-guide-where-to-go</link>
      <description><p>Every new year brings a host of reasons to choose a destination. We pick new flights, new openings, anniversaries and special events for 2016’s hotlist</p><p><strong>To the Barrier … and beyond<br></strong>With Sir David Attenborough espousing its delights in his <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/21/david-attenborough-great-barrier-reef-australia">latest BBC documentary series</a>, the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/30/great-barrier-reef-australia-holiday-guide">Great Barrier Reef</a> – made up of the 1,400-mile string of islands, coral reefs and sand cays off the Queensland coast – is ready for the rush. One of Attenborough’s programmes features the giant manta rays of Lady Elliot Island, 50 miles from Bundaberg (a four-hour drive from Brisbane), and visitors can check them out on a stay at the island’s <a href="http://www.ladyelliot.com.au/">eco-resort </a>(twins from £83pppn). </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/01/2016-holiday-guide-where-to-go">Continue reading...</a></description>

Photographer Andrew Marshall, whose new <strong><a href="http://www.fotovue.com/">photo-location guidebook</a></strong> gives advice on how to capture UK wildlife, selects 10 picture perfect spots</p><p>For more than 60 years Sir David Attenborough has travelled the world witnessing and sharing amazing wildlife spectacles, but he was first inspired nearer to home, by animals in the UK. From water voles plopping into streams to white-tailed sea eagles soaring over the Highlands, UK habitats support varied populations of birds, mammals, amphibians, fish and reptiles.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/29/10-best-places-photograph-wildlife-uk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sands Hotel, Margate, Kent: review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/07/sands-hotel-margate-kent-review</link>
      <description><p>Margate has been on the up since the opening of the Turner Contemporary five years ago – and this cool hotel on the beach fits right in with the town’s burgeoning confidence</p><p>Down to Margate, went the Chas &amp; Dave song, and for the past 50 years downward did seem to be the direction everything was heading in a town that, as early as the 1730s, was among the first to make going to the seaside a thing. Holidaymakers abandoned it; its pier burned down and wasn’t rebuilt; and the Dreamland pleasure park closed in 2003.</p><p>But we’d come to this corner of Kent to catch a resort on the up: since the opening of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2011/aug/05/kent-coast-art-summer-holiday">Turner Contemporary art gallery</a> five years ago this spring, and especially since <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/jun/24/dreamland-margate-kent-fairground-theme-park">Dreamland reopened last June</a>, terms such as hipster paradise and Shoreditch-on-Sea are regularly applied to Margate. Its <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2014/sep/10/weekend-break-jmw-turner-margate-kent">cute old town</a> is now home to offbeat art galleries, vintage shops and microbreweries. And if there’s one thing Shoreditch types love, it’s somewhere groovy to stay.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/07/sands-hotel-margate-kent-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Culpeper, east London: hotel review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/01/the-culpeper-pub-restaurant-hotel-east-london-review</link>
      <description><p>This establishment is a pub, a great restaurant and now a fairly priced hotel (with a rooftop terrace in the offing) – and each element is handled with panache</p><p>The Culpeper is the gift that keeps on giving: on its ground floor, a pub; a restaurant on the first; skyline views from its reopening-for-the-summer rooftop terrace; and now, on the second floor, five en suite bedrooms at £120 a night B&amp;B. It is an endeavour where succeeding at every level could be tricky, but team Culpeper manages it all with panache.</p><p>It is late afternoon when I check in and the bar is already full, causing drinkers – a mix of London’s young and zestful, City workers and craft-ale fans – to mill around the doors of the pub at the corner of Commercial Street and Wentworth Street.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/01/the-culpeper-pub-restaurant-hotel-east-london-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>10 of the best hostels and lodges … that you have to hike to</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/25/10-best-hostels-lodges-b-and-b-hiking-walking-us-italy--china</link>
      <description><p>These out of the way retreats can only be reached on foot – but the reward for your efforts is a warm welcome and a chance to rest weary legs in spectacular surroundings </p><p><strong>Rifugio Lagazuoi</strong><br>Rifugio Lagazuoi is like a sentinel 2,750m above the spires and green valleys of northern Italy, offering not only panoramic views from its sprawling terrace but also the highest sauna in the Dolomites. Expect hearty local cuisine – such as polenta with roe deer – and a warm welcome from members of the Pompanin family, who have run this walk-in retreat since its construction in 1965. History buffs take note: the refuge is a quick walk away from a vast network of trenches and tunnels dug out by Italian forces during the first world war and restored in the late 1990s as an open-air museum.<br><strong>Getting there</strong><br>Rifugio Lagazuoi is on the summit of Mount Lagazuoi halfway between the resorts of Cortina d’Ampezzo and Alta Badia. It claims the highest point along the 120km Alta Via 1 walking route, which runs through the Dolomites from the emerald green Lake Braies to the historic city of Belluno. Bus transfers to the region are available from the airport in Venice 180km to the south.<br>• <em>Rooms from €42pp, bunks from €30pp, </em><a href="http://www.rifugiolagazuoi.com/indexUK.php"><em>rifugiolagazuoi.com</em></a><em>. Open Dec-March, June-Oct; minimum 2 hours trekking time</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/25/10-best-hostels-lodges-b-and-b-hiking-walking-us-italy--china">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 industrial-chic hotels and hostels</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/18/top-10-industrial-chic-hotels-hostels-new-york-bangkok-berlin-tokyo</link>
      <description><p>If you’re a fan of the raw concrete and exposed brick aesthetic, book into one of these converted factories or offices where the design is bare, bold and beautiful </p><ul><li><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/07/top-10-industrial-chic-restaurants-exhibition-spaces-architecture">10 of the best industrial-chic spaces</a></strong></li></ul><p>With beds made from wire fencing (don’t worry, the mattresses on top are normal) and communal spaces that resemble a car park or a building site, this design hotel in the town of Ipoh is as stripped-back as it gets. The hotel occupies a three-storey neo-classical building that used to be a hostel for theatre performers (the theatre burned down in the 1950s), and the ground floor is a popular coffee shop and locals’ hangout. The rooms have many design flourishes: there are thick stage-like curtains separating the en suite bathrooms and outside courtyard, concrete ledges serve as shelves and an assortment of fittings hanging from the ceilings also evoke a sense of being backstage in a theatre. Sekeping has other similarly designed retreats around Malaysia, all with this signature aesthetic.<br tabindex="-1">•<em tabindex="-1"> Doubles from £40, +601 2227 2745, <a draggable="true" href="http://sekeping.com/kongheng/">sekeping.com</a></em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/18/top-10-industrial-chic-hotels-hostels-new-york-bangkok-berlin-tokyo">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 hotels in the Highlands, Scotland</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/15/top-10-hotels-highlands-scotland-fort-william-loch-ness</link>
      <description><p>Activities, both adventurous and relaxing, abound in the Highlands and with these hotel suggestions from a new book, <a href="https://www.harpercollins.co.uk/9780007559343/scotland-the-best">Scotland the Best</a>, great food, hospitality and a good rest are also easy to find</p><p>A Victorian mansion with lawns down to Loch Shiel and the Glenfinnan Monument over the water. There’s no shortbread-tin twee or tartan carpet here; instead a warm welcome from the MacFarlanes and managers, the Gibsons, and an atmospheric bar (with music on Thursdays). Try smoked venison or kippers for breakfast before heading out to explore the Glenfinnan area on foot, or by boat – on a loch cruise (<a href="http://highlandcruises.co.uk/">highlandcruises.co.uk</a>) or for the more energetic, a kayak, (<a href="http://www.rockhopperscotland.co.uk/">rockhopperscotland.co.uk</a>). Great for kids and quintessentially Scottish.<br>• <em>Doubles from £140 B&amp;B, 01397 722235, </em><a href="http://glenfinnanhouse.com/"><em>glenfinnanhouse.com</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/15/top-10-hotels-highlands-scotland-fort-william-loch-ness">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The New Inn, Great Limber, Lincolnshire: hotel review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/09/new-inn-great-limber-lincolnshire-hotel-review</link>
      <description><p>Our reviewer puts aside his political prejudices and laps up the Downton Abbey-dreamscape, top food and idyllic setting of this swanky country pub on a posh estate</p><p>We lefties have a vexed relationship with the landed aristocracy. But if the gentry must persist, can we agree that the least it can do is open more swanky country pubs on its estates? Comrades, we cannot expropriate their land, but they owe us a nice weekend away.</p><p>Welcome to Brocklesby Estate, home of the Earls of Yarborough: a 27,000-acre, Downton Abbey dreamscape in the Lincolnshire Wolds. Amid its fields, fens and tied houses is the tiny village of Great Limber and the New Inn, a grade II-listed brick pub reopened in 2014. It’s been given a Farrow &amp; Ball makeover – that standard gastropub aesthetic – but off-beat, personal Yarborough artefacts make interesting diversions. There are sentimental personal effects (an Inuit fancy dress outfit, worn at a family party), specially commissioned sculptures and light fittings, and an old stable door, all hung like works of art.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/09/new-inn-great-limber-lincolnshire-hotel-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Convent, South Woodchester, Cotswolds: hotel review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/02/the-convent-stroud-hotel-restaurant-music-venue-review</link>
      <description><p>Where nuns once lived a simple life, music lovers can now eat, catch an intimate gig and stay the night. But has the new multi-tasking hotel fully found its groove?</p><p>Dearly beloved, we are gathered here today to pay worshipful respect … to food, music and a good, long relax. It may not be an order of service that the enclosed order of nuns who once called the Convent home would have recognised, but secular pleasure at former religious institutions is a very 21st-century thing.</p><p>The Convent, close to Stroud and surrounded by Cotswolds loveliness, is now a boutique hotel with six suites and what it terms a Writer’s Block of eight doubles. It is also a restaurant, private members’ club, music venue and recording studio. However, at first glance it is hard to get a handle on the diversity of what owners Matt and Charlotte Roberts embarked on three years ago when they took over the near-derelict site.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/02/the-convent-stroud-hotel-restaurant-music-venue-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The Ship Inn, Elie, Fife, Scotland: hotel review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/26/ship-inn-fyfe-scotland-hotel-review</link>
      <description><p>New owners have smartened up this seaside pub and added six bedrooms, but it still offers a local welcome, freshly caught seafood and, at low tide, a cricket pitch on the beach</p><p>There was a dog splayed out in front of a crackling fire in the Ship Inn in Elie. We were at the seaside – in the quaintly grand Kingdom of Fife, facing Edinburgh across the Firth of Forth – out of season. Landlord Graham Bucknall poured us a generous gin and tonic (with artisan, Fife-based <a href="http://edenmill.com/gin/">Eden Mill</a>, of course – where doesn’t produce its own gin these days?).</p><p>“Sometimes there are more dogs than people in the bar,” he laughed. “You shouldn’t come here unless your name’s Lassie,” a local propping up the bar quipped. You get the gist.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/26/ship-inn-fyfe-scotland-hotel-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Villa Levens, near, Kendal, Lake District: hotel review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/20/kendal-lake-district-hotel-villa-levens-fells-cumbria</link>
      <description><p>Despite a mildly corporate feel, this Victorian pile in the Lakes redeems itself with historic features and our writer’s favourite luxury: TVs in the bathrooms</p><p>As an atheist, I am unlikely to ever need spiritual guidance in the Lake District. What I do require, however, in an area where hotel room-rates frequently cause me to invoke God’s name in volleys of unchristian language, is more value-for-money accommodation.</p><p>Therefore it gladdens my heart to see that Villa Levens – a handsome Victorian pile originally built as a family home and then used as a convent until 2012 – has been turned into just such a dependable bolthole. Most tourists head straight for the Lakes’ heartlands of Windermere and Ambleside, where, naturally, bedrooms command a premium but here in the relatively unfashionable (and, yes, flatter, less visually striking) southern portion of the Lakes, you can book an unusually spacious, hi-spec double room from £85 a night midweek. Those prices may be less charitable than they were when the Salesian Sisters of St John Bosco ran Villa Levens as a religious retreat, but then they weren’t big on Temple Spa toiletries, smart bathrooms, crisp linens and comfy beds.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/20/kendal-lake-district-hotel-villa-levens-fells-cumbria">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Ness, Shaldon, Devon: hotel review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/12/the-ness-devon-shaldon-hotel-restaurant-review</link>
      <description><p>There is a distinct nautical feel to the decor of this attractive hotel. Unfortunately the cooking is also all at sea</p><p>Our arrival in Shaldon instantly put me into a holiday mood. Driving over the bridge from Teignmouth, the harbour sparkling in the sunshine, we entered the village in full celebratory swing, bedecked in bunting for the annual <a href="http://www.shaldon-devon.co.uk/Shaldon-Regatta">Shaldon regatta</a>, with sailors spilling out of the pubs. The road got narrower and narrower, and just as I thought we’d have to get out of the car and walk, we turned the corner and there was the hotel.</p><p>Built in 1812 as a summer home for Lord Clifford, the Ness stands above the village, apart not just in location but in style too. In the heart of the village it’s all pastel Georgian cottages, while the Ness looks like a colonial villa, with a wrought iron balcony running round the front and sides.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/12/the-ness-devon-shaldon-hotel-restaurant-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Take the kids to … the National Museum of Flight, Scotland</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/07/national-museum-of-flight-scotland-day-trip</link>
      <description><p>Two huge hangars in East Lothian, east of Edinburgh, have been given a multimillion-pound refurb to bring aviation history to life. And there’s a Concorde, too</p><p><strong>In a nutshell</strong><br>Stretching across the former East Fortune airfield, this feels less like a museum and more like a full day out. The jet black hangar housing Scotland’s supersonic retiree, the G-BOAA Concorde, sticks out like a sore thumb against the rolling fields, but it is home to a real jet-age 1970s experience. Climbing the steps and boarding Concorde still gives a buzz. Kids will make straight for the cockpit, which is full of switches, knobs and dials – and no “do not touch” sign.</p><p><strong>Fun fact</strong><br>When Concorde arrived in 2004, it squeezed into its hangar with four inches to spare – but only once they took the doors off. Visitor numbers doubled.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/07/national-museum-of-flight-scotland-day-trip">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/29/bewilderwood-norfolk-kids-adventure-playground-family-days-out</link>
      <description><p>In this neck of the woods, children explore mazes, zoom around on zipwires and listen to engrossing stories. For adults, there are always the trees to admire</p><p>This gigantic adventure playground is a welcome antidote to soft play parks: there are no grubby plastic balls here, just epic tree-high mazes, rope bridges, slides and zipwires.     <item>
      <title>Spanish steps: family hiking in the Picos de Europa</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/21/family-hiking-holiday-picos-de-europa-asturias-northern-spain</link>
      <description><p>A family break in the mountains of northern Spain made for happy wanderers of all ages – though language skills and a cagoule may be essential</p><p>Hiking holidays with kids can go badly wrong. One walking trip we did was cited long afterwards by our youngest as an infliction of cruelty. But we had much better luck in northern Spain’s Picos de Europa range. In part this was down to the beauty of the mountains, which are dramatically steep and craggy – the Dolomites of Spain.</p><p>Our first walk, the 10km Bajo los Picos trail above Mogrovejo village, began with a long uphill slog through forest, inspiring grumbles of “I’m not doing this again,” till the trees suddenly opened up, to reveal a wall of mountains right above us, dizzyingly precipitous. Thereafter, the views were so captivating that complaints halted.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/21/family-hiking-holiday-picos-de-europa-asturias-northern-spain">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/spain">Spain holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/walkingholidays">Walking holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/familyholidays">Family holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/europe">Europe holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/travel">Travel</category>
      <pubDate>Thu, 21 Apr 2016 05:30:41 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/21/family-hiking-holiday-picos-de-europa-asturias-northern-spain</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/48baa22defbf017a52cebed58263f0ce87f39523/0_61_5120_3072/5120.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=4d57ca9f6d4df2ae5e7176d2f9087c52">

    <item>
      <title>Take the kids to … Puzzlewood, Forest of Dean</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/25/puzzlewood-forest-of-dean-gloucestershire-family-day-trips</link>
      <description><p>An enchanted, mystical wood makes for contented kids and adults on a trip where smart technology meets traditional fun</p><p><strong>In a nutshell</strong><br>A maze of mysterious pathways, cut between moss-covered rocks (known as scowles), occupying an enchanted wood, in the middle of the Forest of Dean. Gandalf eat your heart out. Elves and trolls, fairies and gnomes, it feels like anything and anyone could peek out at you in this magical, mythical landscape. No set trails, just reach a fork in the path and choose your route. A place where your kids – and your imagination – can run wild.</p><p><strong>Fun fact</strong><br>Film crews love it almost as much as the kids. Sequences for television shows Merlin, Doctor Who, and Atlantis have been shot here, as have scenes for the movies Jack the Giant Slayer, and Star Wars: The Force Awakens.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/25/puzzlewood-forest-of-dean-gloucestershire-family-day-trips">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Take the kids to … Warwick Castle</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/24/warwick-castle-review-kids-maze-horrible-histories</link>
      <description><p>William the Conqueror’s medieval fortress triumphs over its theme park trappings, though the new Horrible Histories maze needs time to bed in</p><p><strong>In a nutshell<br></strong>This castle, built by William the Conqueror, is now in the hands of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/merlin-entertainments">Merlin Entertainments</a> (owner of mega attractions such as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/oct/23/take-kids-to-legoland-windsor">Legoland</a>, Alton Towers, Sea Life Centres and the London Eye). The site has been turned into a theme park but the epic stronghold, one of the finest in the country, remains the centrepiece.</p><p><strong>What’s new?</strong><br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/24/warwick-castle-review-kids-maze-horrible-histories">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Take the kids to ... Cadbury World, Birmingham</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/21/cadbuty-world-birmingham-take-the-kids-to</link>
      <description><p>It may not be the Willy Wonka-like experience the writer hoped for but chocolate lovers and kids will enjoy this attraction dedicated to the history and production of the sweet stuff</p><p><strong>In a nutshell<br></strong>In a chocolate box, more like … everything you ever wanted to know about chocolate, under one roof. The tone is set at the ticket booth where everyone gets three bars (a Crunchy, Dairy Milk and – oh yes! – a Curly Wurly) to munch on while taking the self-guided tour on the history and the production of chocolate and the earnest, philanthropic Cadbury family, before entering the factory and then riding through a “chocolate wonderland”.</p><p><strong>(Not so) fun fact</strong><br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/21/cadbuty-world-birmingham-take-the-kids-to">Continue reading...</a></description>
