    <item>
      <title>Take the kids to … Willows Activity Farm, Hertfordshire</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/23/willows-activity-farm-hertfordshire-family-day-trips</link>
      <description><p>Farm fun is on the agenda here, so expect tractors, animals and crop-picking at an attraction that’s great for younger kids, though not so hot on the hot food front</p><p><strong>In a nutshell<br></strong>A family activity farm with “a fun-packed programme whatever the weather”, provided you have a car (to minimise travel hassle) and it’s sunny. Off season, a lot of the toilets and outdoor features are closed, and it’s so quiet you can hear the M25. But go in summer – and for its Easter events – and you’ll get your money’s worth.</p><p> <strong>Best thing about it<br></strong>Tractors, farm animals … what’s not to like for younger kids? Currently, running until 28 March, there are Easter shows, egg hunts, stories and a meet-and-greet with the Easter bunny. On 2 April, it also launches a Peter Rabbit-themed adventure playground. Wholesome outdoorsy activities, such as baby animal handling, pig-racing and lamb bottle-feeding demonstrations, make a good antidote for kids who have had too much iPad time recently.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/23/willows-activity-farm-hertfordshire-family-day-trips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Take the kids to … HintHunt, London</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/22/hinthunt-escape-game-london-family-daytrips</link>
      <description><p>If your idea of hell is being locked in a room, give this enthralling escape game a miss: your team has just one hour to crack the clues and get out of there</p><p><strong>In a nutshell</strong><br>Escape games are <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/apr/03/room-escape-games-city-breaks-gaming">popping up all over the UK</a>, but HintHunt is where it all started. Your team (three to five people, kids aged 9+ with a parent) is locked in a room and has 60 minutes to solve clues and crack codes to get yourselves out. There are two types of room to choose from: a 1940s detective’s office and a Japanese Zen room. “Look everywhere,” they told us before we went in. “Be suspicious of every single object.” A big screen on the wall counts down the minutes but also feeds you helpful hints if you’re really stuck. Yep, someone is watching your every move.</p><p><strong>Fun fact</strong><br>The success rate is 50% for the detective room and 45% for the Zen room. It’s no doddle.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/22/hinthunt-escape-game-london-family-daytrips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Starry Skies festival: go wild in the country</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/13/starry-skies-kids-festival-welsh-borders-herefordshire</link>
      <description><p>Kids get the run of the Welsh Borders countryside at this small friendly festival, but there are plenty of activities, too, if they tire of all that unaccustomed freedom. Plus five more kids’ festivals</p><p>Before we left, George’s mum made me swear not to let our six-year-old-son out of my sight for the duration of the festival. Even as I was nodding in agreement I knew keep this promise would be almost impossible – but I didn’t reckon on breaking it quite so spectacularly or, as things turned out, so willingly.</p><p>Before I’d even finished putting our tent up on the festival site, George was making new friends with kids a few pitches down. Fifteen minutes later, he came and asked me, his face aglow with excitement, if he could go and explore the forest with Ravi and Jasper, his new mates – on their own!</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/13/starry-skies-kids-festival-welsh-borders-herefordshire">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Butlins Astonishing Family Science Weekend: review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/09/butlins-astonishing-family-science-weekend-break-review</link>
      <description><p>Science, fun and Butlins collide at this enlightening three-night family resort break that gets the balance between learning and laughter spot on</p><p>My father was a control and instrumentation engineer. I was never very clear what that meant. I was the one mumbling at the back when we had those “What my dad does for a living” talks at school (it was the 1970s – it was never mum). He was always trying to get me to join him in soldering things on the kitchen table but I could never summon up any enthusiasm for such a strange, smelly activity. I left science behind as soon as I got to choose my A-levels.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/11/top-10-waterparks-uk-europe">Top 10 waterparks in the UK and Europe</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/09/butlins-astonishing-family-science-weekend-break-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 family hotels and campsites in Europe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/12/top-10-family-hotel-villa-holiday-accommodation-europe</link>
      <description><p>These small hotels and campsites, all set in gorgeous locations, strike just the right balance between being child-friendly and appealing to parents who don’t want to feel like they are holidaying in a giant creche </p><p>Lanzarote is a brilliant destination for young kids, with attractions aplenty and funky towns set into beautiful deserty scenery that will satisfy parents’ lust for the exotic, all within a four-hour flight. It’s easy to drive around exploring otherworldly landscapes, epic beaches, seawater swimming pools, the volcanic <a href="http://www.discoverlanzarote.com/timanfaya.asp">Timanfaya national park</a>, César Manrique’s incredible Bond villain homes and his underground caves development Jameos del Agua, with cafe, gardens, pools and auditorium. And there are dozens of easy places to eat – early. One fab place to stay is Casa Tomaren, handily in the centre of the island, consisting of eight villas around a tropical sunken garden with pool and astro turf. The big buffet breakfasts feature cakes, eggs to order and particularly delicious croissants. Its grounds have plenty to interest toddlers – buddha statues, roaming cats and cacti – and massages and yoga are available. The only hitch is the lack of baths, which may cause tears if your tot is a shower-refusenik. <br>•<em> Studio villa (sleeps 2) from €113 a night, 2-bedroom villa (sleeps 4) €236, </em><a href="http://tomaren.es"><em>tomaren.es</em></a><em>. Or try Lanzarote Retreats’ fab eco-friendly, self-catering hideaways on the beach at Arrieta, with a choice of cottages, yurts and villas. Travel cots or foldingbeds and baby/toddler equipment are supplied, there’s a solar-heated pool and kids’ play area, and they can help collect eggs. One week from €700, </em><a href="http://lanzaroteretreats.com/"><em>lanzaroteretreats.com</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/12/top-10-family-hotel-villa-holiday-accommodation-europe">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Top 10 family farmstay holidays in the UK</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-family-farm-stay-holidays-uk</link>
      <description><p>As well as collecting eggs and petting animals, these farmstays offer loads of indoor and outdoor facilities to keep kids – and their parents – happily occupied</p><ul><li><strong>Top 10 UK <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-cabins-and-lodges-for-families-uk">cabins</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-youth-hostels-with-family-rooms-uk">hostels</a> for families</strong></li></ul><p>Shetland ponies, kune-kune pigs and pygmy goats are among the sociable animals on this small farm near Padstow. Four of the seven cottages sleep four, and most have log-burners and gardens or patios. The indoor pool is open from Easter to October, the games room has table football, table tennis and air hockey, and there’s a trampoline, sandpit and play equipment outdoors. Tickets to nearby Crealy Adventure Park last seven days, and sandy beaches await on the Camel estuary.<br>• <em>From £385 a week for four, 01841 540574, </em><a href="https://www.trevorrick.co.uk/"><em>trevorrick.co.uk</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-family-farm-stay-holidays-uk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>From Wondercrump to the Witches: where to experience the world of Roald Dahl</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/08/roald-dahl-100-anniversary-events-wondercrump-the-witches</link>
      <description><p>With 2016 marking the 100th anniversary of Roald Dahl’s birth, the year ahead is filled with celebrations of his life and much-loved stories. Here’s our pick</p><p><strong>Southbank Centre,</strong> <strong>London, 10 February-3 July</strong><br>The Wondercrump World of Roald Dahl is a guided group tour that will reveal the secrets of the author and the inspirations for some of his characters through an interactive journey with installations and items from the <a href="http://www.roalddahl.com/museum">Roald Dahl Museum and Story Centre </a>in Great Missenden. Part of the<a href="http://www.southbankcentre.co.uk/whatson/festivals-series/imagine-childrens-festival"> Imagine children’s festival.</a> <br>• <em>Adult £10, child £9. Open daily; weekdays 11am-3pm, weekends 10am-6pm, before transferring to Wales Millennium Centre in Cardiff, </em><a href="http://www.southbankcentre.co.uk/whatson/the-wondercrump-world-of-roald-94482"><em>southbankcentre.co.uk</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/08/roald-dahl-100-anniversary-events-wondercrump-the-witches">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Take the kids to … Life Science Centre, Newcastle upon Tyne</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/11/life-science-centre-newcastle-family-day-trips-out</link>
      <description><p>This fun, hands-on science centre’s 4D motion ride, planetarium and theatre shows make for a jam-packed family day out. Just don’t call it a museum!</p><p><strong>In a nutshell</strong><br>Touching exhibits is encouraged at this immersive hub for budding scientists; and note the absence of “museum” in its name. The dome-shaped hall is split into zones: don a white coat and play with potions in the Experiment Zone, or get stuck into magnets, motion and building toys in the Curiosity Zone. Once you’ve emerged blinking from the planetarium – currently showing a 30-minute exploration of our galaxy and a shorter animation for under-sevens – a circuit of the outdoor ice rink (until 21 February) will bring you back to Earth. Visit before 17 April to come face to face with more than 40 famous robots, including rare replicas and original props from Star Wars, Forbidden Planet and Terminator 2: Judgment Day.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/11/life-science-centre-newcastle-family-day-trips-out">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 family adventure holidays in Europe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/10/family-adventure-activity-holidays-europe</link>
      <description><p>These family-friendly adventure holidays answer the call of the wild – but are perfectly doable for a wide range of ages</p><ul><li><strong>Top 10 UK <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-youth-hostels-with-family-rooms-uk">hostels</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-cabins-and-lodges-for-families-uk">cabins</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-family-farm-stay-holidays-uk">farmstays</a> for families</strong></li></ul><p>With dramatic mountains all around, this self-guided cycling holiday with Saddle Skedaddle starting in Fügen (closest airport Innsbruck, 40 minutes’ drive) is along quiet cycle paths in the Tyrolean valleys. It can either be a relaxed introduction to family cycling or faster-paced, depending on the routes chosen each day – though all cyclists will want to ride to the dramatic gorge at <a href="http://www.tyrol.com/things-to-do/attractions/all-attractions/a-wolfsklamm-gorge">Wolfsklamm</a> and swim in the lakes of Krummsee and Reintalersee. Kids will love the Black Hole water slide at the <a href="http://www.tyrol.tl/en/highlights/thermal-baths-water-worlds/erlebnistherme-zillertal/">Zillertal Thermal Baths</a>, plus a trip to the <a href="http://www.festung.kufstein.at/index.php/en/">Kufstein fortress</a> and <a href="http://www.planetarium.at/">planetarium</a> at Schwaz.<br>•<em> Seven days from £525pp half-board including route guidance, bike hire £70 a week, </em><em><a href="https://www.skedaddle.co.uk/family/holiday/Family_Cycling/Austria_-_Tyrolean_Valleys_-_Family_Cycling_Holiday_-_Self_Guided/548/view.rails">skedaddle.co.uk</a></em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/10/family-adventure-activity-holidays-europe">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Take the kids to … Story Museum, Oxford</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/10/story-musuem-oxford-day-trip-take-the-kids-to</link>
      <description><p>This museum is in thrall to the wonder of words with its Narnia and other themed rooms, and a new ‘Animal’ exhibition should boost its magical appeal</p><p><strong>In a nutshell</strong><br>When I was a kid, my fantasy was to step inside the pages of the books I loved: climb up the Magic Faraway Tree or sit on Anne of Green Gables’ bed. This museum is perhaps the closest you’ll get to that. It’s in a huge former Royal Mail depot and the stories are brought to life through imaginatively staged rooms allowing visitors, for example, to step through a wardrobe into the snowy, magical forest of Narnia.</p><p><strong>Fun fact</strong><br>The museum has been unable to unlock two old Post Office strongrooms and likes to speculate that when staff finally drill their way in they will find gold.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/10/story-musuem-oxford-day-trip-take-the-kids-to">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The rise of travelling families and world-schooling</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/29/is-world-schooling-kids-selfish-family-travel-edventures</link>
      <description><p>More families than ever are taking ‘edventures’ – long-term trips where children learn on the road. We talk to nomadic parents about the pros and cons of dropping out to travel the world</p><p>• <em>Would you take your kids out of school for an extended trip? Perhaps you have already taken the plunge? Share your experiences in the comments below</em></p><p><em>• </em><strong>Read more tales of Brits who’ve quit their jobs and found a new life abroad this Saturday’s Travel section</strong></p><p>World-schooling, edventuring, life-learning, whatever you call it, more parents are doing it – if the proliferation of blogs and books by families on round-the-world trips is anything to go by.</p><p>To our minds, they are learning in a more interesting way. We don’t know if we’re right, but it’s our gut instinct</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/29/is-world-schooling-kids-selfish-family-travel-edventures">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 waterparks in the UK and Europe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/11/top-10-waterparks-uk-europe</link>
      <description><p>Leave it up to the kids and they’d probably choose to spend every day at a waterpark. We select 10 of the wettest and wildest in the UK and Europe<br></p><ul><li><strong>More family top 10s: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/10/family-adventure-activity-holidays-europe">adventure holidays in Europe</a>, and UK </strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-youth-hostels-with-family-rooms-uk"><strong>hostels</strong></a><strong>, </strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-cabins-and-lodges-for-families-uk"><strong>cabins</strong></a><strong> and </strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-family-farm-stay-holidays-uk"><strong>farmstays</strong></a><br></li></ul><p>If Sommarland’s 21-metre freefall ride sounds scary, try adding another 10 metres to that drop. That’s what faces those who brave the <a href="http://www.portaventura.co.uk/aquatic-park/aquatic-park-attractions/king-khajuna">King Khajuna slide</a> at Costa Caribe Aquatic – the highest freefall slide in Europe. The Caribbean-themed park is just over an hour from Barcelona by car or direct train and has thousands of tropical plants as well as beaches and palm trees. It is part of the huge PortAventura resort and theme park, which is one of the most popular on the continent.<br>• <em>Over-11s €22.80, 4-10s €22, open May-September, </em><a href="http://www.portaventura.co.uk/aquatic-park"><em>portaventura.co.uk</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/11/top-10-waterparks-uk-europe">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 UK cabins and lodges for families</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-cabins-and-lodges-for-families-uk</link>
      <description><p>Indulge the kids’ storybook fantasies with a stay in these wooden huts, wigwams and camping pods around Britain – electricity (and Wi-Fi) by no means guaranteed</p><ul><li><strong>Top 10 UK <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-youth-hostels-with-family-rooms-uk">hostels</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-family-farm-stay-holidays-uk">farmstays</a> for families</strong></li></ul><p>Go off grid in one of two tent-shaped wooden eco-cabins on a conservation farm in the Weald AONB. Each single-room hut, lit by rechargeable lanterns, has a hand-built double bed and two single sofabeds, plus an indoor gas burner and outside fire pit. The shared composting loos and wood-fired showers reflect the low-carbon ethic of the small site, which also has two one-room cottages-on-wheels. Children can help feed farm animals, and Bodiam Castle and Camber Sands are nearby. <br>• <em>From £190 for two nights, reopens Easter, 01797 260890, </em><em><a href="http://www.swallowtailhill.com/">swallowtailhill.com</a></em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-cabins-and-lodges-for-families-uk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 UK youth hostels with family rooms</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-youth-hostels-with-family-rooms-uk</link>
      <description><p>Take advantage of low hostel prices without having to share with snoring strangers by picking a family room in one of these popular UK locations</p><ul><li><strong>Top 10 UK <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-cabins-and-lodges-for-families-uk">cabins</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-family-farm-stay-holidays-uk">farmstays</a> for families</strong></li></ul><p>Safestay has a reputation for opening stylish affordable hostels inside interesting buildings, but this new one really raises the bar. Within easy reach of attractions such as the Natural History Museum and Portobello Market, this is a Jacobean mansion dating back to 1605 and has courtyard garden, stone mullions, leaded lights and a squat 1950s annexe – OK, you can’t have everything. But Safestay has even turned this to its advantage: the somewhat unattractive addition is a modernistic home to a lounge, cafe and pool room with views of the Grade I-listed main building. This follows the usual pattern: dorms have bunkbeds with lockers, curtains and reading lights – all very neat and efficient – if there are three of you, take a triple-decker. For the price in this location, it is exceptional.<br>• <em>Dorm bed from £15, four-bed private room from £80, </em><a href="https://www.safestay.com/ss-london-holland-park.html"><em>safestay.com</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-youth-hostels-with-family-rooms-uk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Bonjour Brittany: a toddler-friendly holiday in rural France</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/family-holiday-brittany-france-toddler-farm-stay</link>
      <description><p>Our writer heads for the Brittany coast to kick back in a farmhouse B&amp;B that combines style and a wealth of vintage finds, while still staying toddler-friendly</p><p>Brittany, to me, means family holidays. In a faded photo album somewhere at home there’s a record of the summers I spent there as a child with my parents, grandparents and two sisters – racing around on a beach under thunderous skies; long, messy picnic lunches; a tangle of tanned limbs packed into an old Volvo.</p><p>Over 30 years later I’m back with partner Will and 18-month-old Betsy at La Maison des Lamour, a 15th-century farmhouse with five B&amp;B rooms and four self-catering cottages near Plélo, 15 minutes’ drive from the north coast and three hours from Cherbourg. (We chose a three-hour daytime ferry crossing from Portsmouth – a sleepless night with a child on an overnight ferry is no way to start a holiday.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/family-holiday-brittany-france-toddler-farm-stay">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Family holidays: bludgeon your plans through … they’ll thank you for it one day</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/family-holidays-walking-adventure-children</link>
      <description><p>Grit your teeth, it’s time to plan your family trip. If you need help, here’s Kevin Rushby with tips on what makes a great one<br></p><ul><li><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-cabins-and-lodges-for-families-uk">Top 10 UK cabins and lodges for families</a> | </strong><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/top-10-family-farm-stay-holidays-uk">Top 10 UK family farmstays</a> | </strong><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/family-holiday-brittany-france-toddler-farm-stay">Toddler-friendly holiday in rural France</a></strong></li></ul><p>When I ask Maddy (12) which has been her favourite family trip ever, she says, without any need for reflection, “<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/sep/05/great-eastern-europe-road-trip-slovakia-high-tatra">Walking in Slovakia – the Tatra mountains</a> – all those days we did going from hut to hut.” Now you might nod and think this seems reasonable. The Tatras are an impressively jagged range, with forbidding gorges, snowy summits and paths that cling to cliffs over precipices. There is plenty to conjure great imaginings of hobbits, perhaps, or Frozen’s Arendelle. It is certainly a landscape for adventure that any child might love, and the huts are magical caverns of hospitality and warmth.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/07/family-holiday-accommodation-europe-readers-travel-tips-france-italy-austria">Family accommodation in Europe: readers’ tips</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/09/family-holidays-walking-adventure-children">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The insiders’ guide  to finding a cheaper holiday in 2016</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/04/cheap-holiday-guide-2016-insider-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>Travel experts reveal how to track down the best-value flights and accommodation, and where to look for the best online deals</p><p>• Savvy travellers know to delete their browser history because prices can increase based on the number of times you re-enter a particular website, says Phil Bloomfield, spokesperson at <a href="http://www.cheapflights.co.uk/">Cheapflights.co.uk</a>. The company’s data shows that the cheapest days to book are Tuesdays, generally about 50 days ahead of departure, he adds. “Another hack is to travel between 6pm and midnight when flights are typically cheaper than those early in the morning. Air fares tend to be at their most expensive three days before travel and Friday is consistently the most expensive day to fly, so if possible, try to avoid those if you can.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/04/cheap-holiday-guide-2016-insider-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Laos town known for drunkenness and tourist deaths cleans up its act</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/09/vang-vieng-laos-tubing-calm-activities</link>
      <description><p>The town of Vang Vieng in Laos was once synonymous with backpacker excess, but now offers adventure activities that make the most of its stunning location</p><p>“I want us to preserve the mountains of Vang Vieng, the river and the culture for the future,” Thanongsi Solangkoun told me as I sipped mulberry wine at his organic restaurant on the Nam Song river in Laos.</p><p>Thanongsi, affectionately known as Mr T, produces some three tonnes of mulberries every year, 80 litres of goat’s milk a week, plus avocados, papayas and mangoes at his organic <a href="http://www.laofarm.org/">Lao Farm</a> (dorm beds from £3, private rooms and mud huts from £13), 2½ miles north of Vang Vieng town. He also runs a restaurant, a guesthouse, a cooking school, a volunteer programme, and a local education project on the farm.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/09/vang-vieng-laos-tubing-calm-activities">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/29/readers-travel-photography-competition-may</link>
      <description><p>Our monthly photo competitions have no theme this year: we just want your best travel shots. Enter via <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/56fbbadfe4b00bae9a99a667">GuardianWitness</a> and you could win a seven-night ‘Secret Fjords’ <a href="https://www.discover-the-world.co.uk/destinations/iceland-holidays/secret-fjords">self-drive holiday to Iceland</a> for two with Discover the World</p><p>Have you taken a particularly stunning snap on your recent travels? A glimmering river at dawn? A pungent street-scene? A rare bird bursting from the undergrowth? Whatever it is and wherever it was taken, we want to see <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/572339e9e4b0a2f120514939">your best travel photograph</a>.</p><p>We’ll choose and publish a selection of our favourites, and the winning image will be mounted and displayed to the public with the other monthly winners in an end-of-year exhibition at the Guardian offices in London. Plus digital printers <a href="http://www.point101.com/">Point 101</a> will send you a copy of your winning shot to hang on your own wall.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/29/readers-travel-photography-competition-may">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>This week, we’re looking for insider tips on lively, francophone metropolis of Montreal. Let us know about the sights, scenes and secrets you’ve found on your travels</p><p>Have you been to the so-called ‘Paris of Canada’? If so, we’d love to hear your personal recommendations. If you’ve discovered a cheerful guesthouse, a revealing excursion, a backstreet museum or a curious day trip, let us know.</p><p>Send us your tips via <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/">GuardianWitness</a> including as much detail as you can in <strong>around</strong> <strong>100 words</strong> (along with website, menu details and prices etc, if possible).<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/11/montreal-travel-tips-competition">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Holidays in Tuscany: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/05/tuscany-holidays-readers-italy-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>Besides Florence, Siena and San Gimignano, this beautiful region has many untrodden corners and family-run places to eat and stay. Readers pick their favourites</p><p>I was as surprised as anyone to discover a small-scale sustainable goat farm, with some of the finest cashmere I’ve ever seen, in the heart of Tuscany, close to Radda in Chianti. Owner Nora Kravis (originally from Long Island, in the States) is a character, having lived here for over 30 years and owning more than 200 goats (one named Cappuccino) and 15 dogs. You can arrange a visit – Nora loves guests – and check out her shop and its range of delightful cashmere accessories.<br>• <em><a href="http://www.chianticashmere.com/Homepage-475/">chianticashmere.com</a></em><br><strong>Georgette Jupe</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/05/tuscany-holidays-readers-italy-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Local tours and guides in Cuba: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/28/cuba-havana-local-tours-guides-gay-bars-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>From gay bars in Havana to exotic wildlife in the countryside, our readers reveal how using local tour guides is a great way to discover Cuba</p><p>Though homosexuality was legalised in Cuba in 1979, much of Havana’s gay scene, like the best of its culture, is still underground. A great way to see it all is with a guide, and there can be few better than the hugely informative <a href="http://www.gaycuba.me/home.html">Yunior Crespo</a>. A tour will probably start in the Plaza del Cathedral and end up with mojitos in the heaving gay bars on Calle 23, via an art gallery, a supper club and salsa dancing. <br><strong>brownjamesmatthew1</strong><br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/28/cuba-havana-local-tours-guides-gay-bars-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Pubs, cafes and tearooms for walkers: readers’ tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/21/pubs-cafes-tearooms-for-walkers-hikers-uk</link>
      <description><p>That pie and pint, or tea and cake, are never so welcome as when you’ve earned them with a long hike. Readers reveal their favourite walkers’ pitstops </p><p>In the heart of the inspiring mid-Wales countryside, surrounded by a network of delightful, often spectacular, footpaths, the Cwtch community cafe is in the old miners’ village of Pontrhydygroes. <em>Cwtch</em> has two meanings in Welsh – a cosy nook, and a cuddle. You don’t usually get a cuddle on arrival, but the welcome is warm and the cakes delicious. The cafe provides simple lunches and sandwiches, and doubles as a well-stocked village shop. There is everything here that a walker could desire – including good company, and even secondhand books. The surrounding landscapes include gorges, waterfalls, ancient woodlands and moorlands.<br>•<em> on </em><em><a href="https://www.facebook.com/cwtch.pontrhydygroes">Facebook</a><br></em><strong>Richard Hartnup</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/21/pubs-cafes-tearooms-for-walkers-hikers-uk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Great UK tearooms: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/14/uk-tearooms-cafes-readers-tips-cakes-sandwiches</link>
      <description><p>This very British institution is thriving despite the rise of trendy coffee shops. At these favourites you’ll find excellent tea and cakes – plus Victorian costumes, edible chocolate compost and even a supper club </p><p>What a wonderful little discovery. With a fantastic location in the pretty <a href="http://eastdevon.gov.uk/parks-gardens-and-recreation/parks-and-gardens/manor-gardens-exmouth/history-of-manor-gardens/">Manor Gardens</a>, and just off the beach, it’s a little trendy gem of naughtiness. Creme egg brownies, stacks and stacks of homemade fluffy pancakes, arty sketches on the walls and great fresh proper coffee. The best thing of all though (aside from the cute surfer-looking staff) are the incredible homemade scones. Award-winning scones in fact ... they’re blinking perfect, exactly the right amount of crumble, flavour and Devonshire clotted cream. Let the kids break free in the gardens and get stuck in. We had a wonderful afternoon there, a little cherished family moment, proper lush!<br>• <a href="http://www.bumbleandbee.co.uk/"><em>bumbleandbee.co.uk</em></a><br><strong>sachapaisley</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/14/uk-tearooms-cafes-readers-tips-cakes-sandwiches">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Highlights of Slovenia: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/31/slovenia-lakes-mountains-caves-readers-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>For a country of just two million people, Slovenia has much more than its share of sights and attractions. Readers pick their favourites outside of capital Ljubljana</p><p>As you walk round Lake Bled, past Villa Bled, a little sign saying “Tearoom” points upwards through the trees. It gives no indication of the wow factor this tearoom commands. Once used by President Tito, it recently reopened with the original furniture and photos. Have a cup of coffee on the patio with its stunning floor mosaics of wild animals, while you look out over the lake towards the church, and the castle beyond. It is a treasure of pure elegance, the prices are ridiculously reasonable and the coffee just gorgeous!<br><em>• <a href="http://www.lakeblednews.com/cafe-belvedere/">lakeblednews.com/cafe-belvedere</a><br></em><strong>cuddlekitten</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/31/slovenia-lakes-mountains-caves-readers-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Our monthly photo competitions have no theme this year: we just want your best travel shots. Enter via <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/56fbbadfe4b00bae9a99a667">GuardianWitness</a> and you could win a seven-night <a href="https://www.discover-the-world.co.uk/destinations/iceland-holidays/secret-fjords">‘Secret Fjords’ self-drive holiday to Iceland for two with Discover the World</a></p><p>Whether it’s the widescreen appeal of landscapes or capturing small details on a memorable trip, we want you to <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/56fbbadfe4b00bae9a99a667">send in your best travel imagery</a>.</p><p>The winning image will be mounted and displayed to the public with the other monthly winners in an end-of-year exhibition at the Guardian offices in London.     <item>
      <title>Thailand's best street food: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/24/best-street-food-restaurants-thailand</link>
      <description><p>Spicy, salty, sweet, sour and absolutely delicious … readers pick their favourite street eats and local budget restaurants across Thailand</p><p>In Thailand there are many places to eat good seafood but, for me, one of the best and cheapest and freshest is a small active fishing village at the foot of Khoa Takieb (Chopstick Mountain) in Hua Hin, with the native macaques looking on. There are many small restaurants along the town’s main street, with tanks of live fish, prawns and crabs, shellfish. For me, the real draw is the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horseshoe_crab">horseshoe crab</a>, a prehistoric creature that scientists call a living fossil as it’s over 450 million years old. The Thais prepare this as a typically spicy salad, made with the eggs of the crab, and serve it in the alien-like shell. To order in Thai , ask for <em>yam meng da</em> or <em>yam meng da talay</em>. If the crab isn’t to your taste there are many other great things on offer, such as grilled scallops with garlic.<br><strong>Ben Hann</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/24/best-street-food-restaurants-thailand">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Things to do in Dublin: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/17/things-to-do-in-dublin-ireland-readers-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>If you like history and pubs, Dublin might just be your favourite city, but there’s more: great gardens, fashion, architecture, a superb cemetery and walks </p><p>The famous <a href="http://faganspub.ie/">Fagan’s Pub</a> in Drumcondra is where the then taoiseach Bertie Ahern stopped the traffic to bring Bill Clinton for a jar on his visit to Dublin in 2000, and where the photos on the walls document all the famous customers as well as the rich local history. Start there then take a short walk down Millmount Avenue to Griffith Park and follow the Tolka river to the <a href="http://www.botanicgardens.ie/">National Botanic Gardens</a> (free entry). The Palm House is breathtaking – look for the plaque marking the spot where the great philosopher Wittgenstein, who lived in Dublin for a couple of years after the second world war, liked to sit. The gardens allows direct access to <a href="http://www.glasnevintrust.ie/">Glasnevin Cemetery</a> (entry free) – Dublin’s Père Lachaise – and a focal point of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/25/easter-rising-tour-dublin-google-maps-colin-farrell">1916 centenary commemorations</a>. Exiting the cemetery at the south gate (not the main gate) you enter Prospect Square and can finish the walk with a pint in <a href="https://www.facebook.com/JohnKavanaghTheGravediggers/">John Kavanagh’s pub</a>, known locally as the Gravediggers. This is one of Dublin’s most atmospheric old pubs and a world away from the tourist trap that is the Temple Bar area. <br><strong>Lubetkin</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/17/things-to-do-in-dublin-ireland-readers-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Best places to eat and drink in Japan: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/10/best-places-eat-drink-in-japan-readers-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>It might not be hard to find great sushi in Tokyo, or a gem of a sake bar, but where would you go for the best okonomiyaki pancakes, takoyaki octopus balls, gold ice-cream or udon noodles?</p><p>I’ve eaten the most rarefied meals of my life in Japan, but it’s hard to beat the charms of a £2 portion of takoyaki – fluffy balls of eggy batter studded with boiled octopus, ginger and spring onion – in a polystyrene tray. These are anointed with takoyaki sauce (Japan’s answer to HP) and mayonnaise, then sprinkled with dried pink bonito (skipjack tuna) flakes, which writhe in the heat emanating from the molten core. You spear each ball with a notched cocktail stick and nibble while trying to avoid singing your lips. It’s like eating mouthfuls of octopus-flavoured cloud. Osaka invented them, but you can find them pretty much everywhere in Japan. Among the best are the ones served in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/mar/10/best-restaurants-kyoto-tokyo-japan-chefs-choice">Kyoto</a>’s <a href="http://www.insidekyoto.com/nishiki-market-downtown-kyoto">Nishiki Market</a>, where you buy a ticket from a vending machine before placing your order with the cook juggling the golden balls.<br><strong>MoragR</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/10/best-places-eat-drink-in-japan-readers-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What to do in Edinburgh: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/03/things-to-do-in-edinburgh-readers-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>A castle in Edinburgh (but not the usual one), cinema nostalgia, up close with live music, and plenty of historic attractions – even beyond the well-known haunts, Auld Reekie has plenty to offer</p><p>Stroll up the Royal Mile and, just past the Canongate Kirk, turn into Chrichton’s Close (next to Starbucks) to discover the haven that is the Scottish Poetry Library, with tasteful modern architecture and a calm and welcoming feel. Browse poetic tomes and biographies, and do buy, at least, a greetings card from Edinburgh’s most literary little gift shop.<br><em>• </em><a href="http://www.scottishpoetrylibrary.org.uk/"><em>scottishpoetrylibrary.org.uk</em></a><br><strong>John Samson</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/03/things-to-do-in-edinburgh-readers-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Boat trips and cruises worldwide: readers’ tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/25/best-boat-trips-and-cruises-readers-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>From following the route of the Vikings to kayaking in the backwaters of Kerala, readers launch themselves into adventures in boats large and small</p><p>Antigua, the island of beaches, is best seen from the sea. For an exciting and downright hair-raising trip try circumnavigating the island on an offshore powerboat. You’ll be swimming with stingrays, snorkelling at the Pillars of Hercules, then lunching on a remote beach, Robinson Crusoe style. You’ll sail into Nelson’s Dockyard as old-time sailors might have done; and see the Shirley Heights lookout as it towers 150 metres above the sea. The excellent guides point out so many things that you’d never have the opportunity to see from land. You’ll come back from an unforgettable day windblown and wet but exhilarated.<br>• <em>$170 with </em><em><a href="http://keralakayaking.com/kerala-adventure/">adventureantigua.com</a> </em><em><br></em><strong>Ann6Scott</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/25/best-boat-trips-and-cruises-readers-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Favourite Paris bistros: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/18/favourite-paris-bistro-restaurants-readers-travel-tips-france</link>
      <description><p>The streets of Paris thrum with bistros serving tourists and locals traditional and contemporary delights at a wide variety of prices. Our readers help sort the gougères from the crépes</p><p>Just behind the hustle and bustle of the Marais is a hidden little entrance to Jaja, a cosy little alfresco parcel of peace. Not your stereotypical Parisian bistro, Jaja is Paris’s modern alternative. Pick a table in the jungle-like courtyard (if it’s raining, it has a lovely conservatory) and enjoy this hidden gem. The food is gorgeous, and even has vegetarian options, which is rare in the city. All its wines are from independent French vineyards.<br>• <em>3 rue Sainte-Croix de la Bretonnerie, +33 1 42 74 7152, </em><a href="http://jaja-resto.com/"><em>jaja-resto.com</em></a><br><strong>Lottie Chapman</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/18/favourite-paris-bistro-restaurants-readers-travel-tips-france">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>‘My favourite beach in the world’ – readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/11/best-beaches-in-the-world-readers-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>Wild, peaceful, fun, busy, hot ... we all love the seaside, whether it’s just along the coast from Swansea or sweltering under a tropical sky</p><p>Just a winding road away from vibrant Caribbean-infused Puerto Viejo is the <a href="http://www.costarica-nationalparks.com/gandocamanzanillowildliferefuge.html">Gandoca-Manzanillo wildlife refuge</a>, a haven for free-range iguanas, sedentary sloths, all manner of feathered, scaled and furry creatures – and a few lucky human visitors. Explosions of vegetation burst with beneficial botanical properties; the Refuge is a tropical garden of Eden. Follow a trail through the towering bamboo canes, skirt around zig-zagging trails of tiny crabs, and discover a serene, pristine stretch of soft white sand, fringed with coconut palms. The gentle rustle and sway of tropical vegetation blends with the gentle swoosh of the turquoise tide – Punta Uva is a secluded slice of paradise.<br><strong>Laura Hall<br>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/nov/28/costa-rica-holiday-guide-beaches-hotels">Holiday guide to Costa Rica</a></strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/11/best-beaches-in-the-world-readers-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sights to see in Johannesburg, South Africa: readers' travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/11/johannesburg-south-africa-readers-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>From a cycle tour taking in Soweto’s history to a hole-in-the-wall serving Ethiaopian inerja flatbread meals and all the urban regeneration in between – readers share their city favourites</p><p>During the apartheid era, the <a href="http://landlopers.com/2014/04/13/orlando-towers">Orlando power station</a> towers in Soweto used to work as a coal-burning plant for electricity that supplied the northern suburbs of Johannesburg, while local residents remained without electricity. The only “benefit” to the Sowetans was the polluted air. After years of neglect, they have been transformed into an entertainment area – bungee jumping and a restaurant – and they also serve as giant billboards, one specifically with artistic murals encompassing the lifestyle in Soweto and its people.<br><strong>Ebony Walden</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/11/johannesburg-south-africa-readers-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Strange travel encounters: readers’ tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/21/odd-travel-encounters-readers-tips</link>
      <description><p>The most memorable moments in travel are often the most eccentric. From oil wrestling to staring contests, or being entertained over dinner by robots, our readers share their way-out memories</p><p>Everybody knows that Japan has a reputation for being a little bit quirky, but in all my years of travel I have never experienced anything quite like <a href="http://www.timeout.com/tokyo/restaurants/robot-restaurant-1">Tokyo’s Robot Restaurant</a>, in Shinjuku. From the moment you enter the psychedelic waiting room and are handed a robot dinosaur to play with, you know you are in for a “different” night out. The craziness levels ramp up as the dinner show starts; where else would you witness robots fighting giant sharks to a soundtrack of <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?gl=GB&amp;v=9bZkp7q19f0&amp;hl=en-GB">Gangnam Style</a>, accompanied by scantily clad girls whizzing round above your head on swings? It truly has to be experienced to be believed, and your benchmark for “odd” will never be the same again!<br><strong>charlotte54</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/21/odd-travel-encounters-readers-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Backpackers' experiences: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/14/readers-backpackers-trips-adventure-travel</link>
      <description><p>Many of travel’s magic moments come on backpacking trips, when random situations provide a route to adventure. From China and Chile to Sudan and Slovakia, readers share favourite discoveries<br></p><p>The sleeper train journey from Beijing to Siping in Jilin province takes about 11 hours. I was sort of swept to the right compartment by a combination of conductors and passengers. My bunk was the topmost of three and I was halfway up there when a yank on my foot brought me back down again: a fellow passenger wanted to make it clear that I really should take off my shoes. I was then shooed back up the ladder once more. During the night, marching music was piped over the speakers at regular intervals; and at stations, food vendors dangled dried chicken feet and baskets of dumplings through the windows on long sticks.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/14/readers-backpackers-trips-adventure-travel">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Readers' travel photography competition: January</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/11/readers-travel-photography-competition-january</link>
      <description><p>For the first competition of the year, there is no theme – we just want see your best travel shots. Enter your photo via <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/569398b3e4b0962b6cc0e4e4">GuardianWitness</a> and you could win a seven-night <a href="https://www.discover-the-world.co.uk/destinations/iceland-holidays/secret-fjords">‘Secret Fjords’ self-drive holiday to Iceland for two with Discover the World</a> </p><p>From landscape photography to atmospheric shots of a street market to wildlife and nature – this month you are free to send us your best travel shot. Enter your travel shot to be in with a chance of a bagging <a href="https://www.discover-the-world.co.uk/destinations/iceland-holidays/secret-fjords">a self-drive holiday to Iceland for two people</a>.</p><p>The winning image will be mounted and displayed to the public with the other monthly winners in an end-of-year exhibition at the Guardian offices in London. And digital printers <a href="http://www.point101.com/">Point 101</a> will send you a copy of your shot to hang on your own wall. The winner will be entered for the overall prize, a seven-night trip for two people to Iceland, courtesy of <a href="https://www.discover-the-world.co.uk/destinations/iceland-holidays/secret-fjords">Discover the World</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/11/readers-travel-photography-competition-january">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Family accommodation in Europe: readers’ tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/07/family-holiday-accommodation-europe-readers-travel-tips-france-italy-austria</link>
      <description><p>Country camping in France, fun on a farmstay in Austria, or even a ‘tropical’ stay in Germany? Readers recommend places to stay with children across Europe</p><p>This campsite is about 45 minutes inland from the beaches and shopping of Biarritz and 45 minutes from the Pyrenees. It’s ideal for families with kids under 15, with daily organised activities in July and August. The main attraction is horse riding, but for us the best thing is that the kids can run off and do their own thing and we can relax. You can pitch your own tent, or rent an apartment in the old manor house or a safari tent. <br>•<em> Pitch from €5 a night, plus €6 adult, €3 child, apartment from €300 a week, deluxe safari tent from €500 a week, </em><a href="http://esperbasque.co.uk/"><em>esperbasque.co.uk</em> </a><br><strong>Johan Douma<br></strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/jan/07/family-holiday-accommodation-europe-readers-travel-tips-france-italy-austria">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The best of Naples: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/18/best-places-to-visit-in-naples-italy-readers-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>Pizza and archaeology figure strongly for readers who’ve visited the southern Italian city, but so do Vespa tours, literary spots, football and a cult of the dead</p><p>There are different ways of expressing personal spiritual beliefs. In Naples there’s football. On Sundays Neapolitan streets fall silent when the city football team plays. Still, nothing compares to the late 1980s team, the one that won Serie A twice thanks mainly to one player: Diego Armando Maradona. He’s still worshipped in town – just take a walk to Piazzetta Nilo in the city centre, where you will find a light-blue reliquary in which a strand of curly black hair is preserved. Whose is this relic? Maradona’s of course, available to all devotees in search of a miracle for the next Sunday’s match.<br><strong>Francesco talleyrand</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/18/best-places-to-visit-in-naples-italy-readers-travel-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Best beaches in Mexico: readers’ travel tips</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/10/mexico-best-beaches-hotels-hostels-readers-tips</link>
      <description><p>Flour-like sand, cocktails in treehouses, underwater sculptures and whale sharks have all made an impression on visitors to Mexico’s Pacific and Caribbean coasts </p><ul><li><strong>The best budget hotels on Mexico’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/nov/18/top-10-budget-beach-hotels-mexico-pacific-coast-bed-breakfast">Pacific coast</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/feb/16/yucatan-mexico-budget-beach-hotels-hostels">Yucatán peninsula</a></strong></li></ul><p>Hidden away at the far end of Puerto Escondido’s five-mile beach, Punta Zicatela is a cross between surfer paradise and hippy hideaway. By far the best place to swim in town, La Punta is centred on a street of cafes, surf shops, hostels and restaurants. <a href="https://www.facebook.com/Caba%C3%B1as-Buena-Onda-Puerto-Escondido-299810976728208/info/?tab=overview">Cabañas Buena Onda</a> (bed in dorms from about £4) is a simple hostel on the beach offering individual huts, dormitories and tents. The palm trees provide much-needed shade, a place to sling a hammock, and give the place an authentic, jungle feel. There is a simple kitchen and basic washing facilities – don’t go there if you want the full spa treatment – but there are few better places in Mexico to watch the sunset than from one of their beach chairs with a cold Caguama beer. By night, the Punta is generally quiet – jump in a taxi to Zicatela for bars and nightclubs – but there are also plenty of opportunities for card games, impromptu acoustic concerts and stargazing.<br><strong>dompasteiner</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/dec/10/mexico-best-beaches-hotels-hostels-readers-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Readers recommend ancient cities, imposing temples and caves from Mayan, Inca and even earlier cultures </p><p>The cave is in fact a long overhang of rock on the side of a canyon.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/nov/19/laos-holidays-readers-travel-tips</link>
      <description><p>From alternative food and nightlife in Luang Prabang to adventures well off the tourist trail, readers pick their best Laos experiences</p><ul><li><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/series/readers-travel-tips">Send us a tip and you could win a £200 hotel voucher</a></strong></li></ul><p>Don’t be afraid to cross the bamboo bridge over the Mekong.     <item>
      <title>Road trips and fire pits: discovering the secrets of BBQ in Nashville</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/06/road-trips-fire-pits-secrets-of-bbq-nashville-tennessee</link>
      <description><p>Shauna Guinn and her partner searched the deep south for the best American barbecue before opening their own joint in the deep south of ... Wales</p><p><strong>My partner Sam and I wanted to discover the secret of American barbecue.</strong> We gave up our jobs in the UK and busked our way from California to the deep south. The US version of a barbecue is quite different to ours, it’s all about smoking meat in a “pit” for a long time at low temperatures.</p><p><strong>Everyone thinks Nashville is a little honky-tonk town in the middle of Tennessee</strong>. It’s actually quite a commercial place, the beating heart of all the major record companies – there are cowboys walking around with guitars and Stetsons, but they tend to be commercial artists. And it’s not just country music – Jack White from the White Stripes has his main studio there. Broadway, the main strip, is cheesy and tacky, but great for a laugh. One of the most famous bars is <a href="http://www.tootsies.net/">Tootsies</a>, known for craft beer and moonshine. Every bar in Nashville has live bands, and the musicianship is unbelievable, even at the smallest joints.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/06/road-trips-fire-pits-secrets-of-bbq-nashville-tennessee">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/nashville">Nashville holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/travelfoodanddrink">Food and drink</category>

    <item>
      <title>Called to the bars: a negroni tour of London</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/06/negroni-tour-london-booze-trips-cocktails</link>
      <description><p>A new London drinks tour focusing on the gin-vermouth-Campari magic that is the negroni takes in clubs, hotels and speakeasies across the city</p><p>“I don’t really know what a negroni is,” confessed my companion who I’d roped in to accompanying me on London’s first negroni-themed tour. Our collective hipster point total plummeted. We were sitting in an upstairs room in <a href="http://www.68andboston.com/">68 &amp; Boston</a>, a wine-and-cocktail bar in Soho, which has a gentleman’s club feel with its panelled walls, corniced ceiling and stained-glass windows. “Gin, vermouth, Campari,” I whispered to my friend who had unwittingly stumbled into this baptism of firewater.</p><p>This was the first stop out of five, as our guides, Leon and Max, took us on a quest to find the best negroni in town. While my friend had no idea what to expect, I had some prior experience. I had attended Leon’s inaugural tour, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2013/aug/23/gin-tour-of-london">a London “gin journey” in 2013</a>. The format was similar: a minibus drives a small group around an eclectic selection of bars, with a cocktail and some good-humoured education at each stop. Since then, Leon has launched the tours in Liverpool, Manchester and, from June, Edinburgh. There are even plans to expand internationally, to Singapore, Sydney, New York and Amsterdam.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/06/negroni-tour-london-booze-trips-cocktails">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 Soviet-era experiences in St Petersburg</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/05/top-10-soviet-era-experiences-st-petersburg-russia</link>
      <description><p>It’s 25 years since the USSR imploded but in St Petersburg there are still plenty of places to experience the highs and lows of the communist era, some of which are looked upon nostalgically by Russians</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2014/aug/16/st-petersburg-russia-rooftop-tour">St Petersburg’s architecture </a>is one of its biggest attractions. The centre’s original baroque and classicism styles have been preserved, so it’s almost as if the USSR never happened here. However, if you travel to the Moskovskiy district you’ll see the full scale of the Stalinist neoclassical architecture. It has been said that the tall grey buildings with giant columns and Soviet insignia were meant to oppress the citizens into obeying the communist party. See for yourself by starting a walk at the end of Moskovsky Prospekt at the Moskovskaya metro station, and then walk back towards its beginning at Sadovaya station. Look out for the two largest, classic examples of the style: the <a href="http://www.saint-petersburg.com/buildings/house-of-soviets/">House of Soviets</a> at 212 Moskovsky Prospekt, and the <a href="https://www.google.co.uk/maps/place/Kofe+Khauz/@59.8646069,30.3209509,3a,75y,84.32h,119.97t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1sDd8KWapNKvtRQx_V22fpEQ!2e0!6s%2F%2Fgeo1.ggpht.com%2Fcbk%3Fpanoid%3DDd8KWapNKvtRQx_V22fpEQ%26output%3Dthumbnail%26cb_client%3Dmaps_sv.tactile.gps%26thumb%3D2%26w%3D203%26h%3D100%26yaw%3D24.95019%26pitch%3D0!7i13312!8i6656!4m2!3m1!1s0x46963aa58b202333:0x965d5f9d3ea433e9!6m1!1e1">Spire Building at 190 Moskovsky Prospekt</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/05/top-10-soviet-era-experiences-st-petersburg-russia">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 US mid-Atlantic national and state parks</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/03/top-10-us-national-state-parks-new-jersey-pennsylvania-delaware-maryland</link>
      <description><p>The eastern states of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware and Maryland offer green spaces with stunning peaks and waterfalls, as well as wonderful wildlife</p><p>The Delaware river forms part of the border between Pennsylvania and New Jersey. In the 1960s the Army Corps of Engineers proposed building a dam along the flood-prone section of river between the New York state line and the coal mining town of East Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania. This would have created a 37-mile lake between Pennsylvania and New Jersey to be called Tocks Island national recreation area. In preparation for flooding the valley, more than 15,000 people were displaced from their homes. Then a geologic study revealed that the proposed dam was on top of several active fault lines and the project was scrapped. In 1978, the property was transferred to the National Park Service and renamed the Delaware Water Gap national recreation area. Today, the park protects 70,000 acres of forest and farmland, 40 miles of the Delaware river and 28 miles of the Appalachian Trail.<br><strong>Top tip</strong> Many picturesque hamlets and villages that stood along the Delaware river were lost to the dam project but some historic buildings remain. The quaint village of Bevans now stands as the <a href="http://www.petersvalley.org/index.cfm">Peters Valley School of Craft</a>, where blacksmithing, woodworking and weaving are taught and practised. Take a tour of the historic grounds on summer weekends or sign up for a two- to five-day workshop between May and September.<br>• <a href="https://www.nps.gov/dewa/index.htm"><em>nps.gov/dewa</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/03/top-10-us-national-state-parks-new-jersey-pennsylvania-delaware-maryland">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why being a vegetarian traveller is often so hard to swallow</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/28/why-being-vegetarian-traveller-hard-to-swallow</link>
      <description><p>Avoiding meat and fish while travelling can be frustrating – if not impossible – but it can also lead to adventures and provide a unique insight into a destination</p><p><strong>• Share your stories of being a vegetarian abroad in the comments</strong></p><p>In India, where I grew up, I was never considered vegetarian enough. I do not eat fish or meat, but I do eat eggs, which meant outing myself as a “non-vegetarian” when someone asked if I am “pure veg”. After all, this is a country <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/23/india-beef-ban-jobs-economy-maharashtra-cows">where states have passed laws banning beef</a>. But in the US, I have met vegetarians who eat chicken. Vegetarians who have casually thrown the term “flexitarian” at me, as if it were a sprinkle of coriander. Vegetarians who are at pains to let you know they are not crazy, like, you know, vegans.</p><p>Over three decades of being vegetarian, I have learned the hard way that there is no universal definition of what a vegetarian is. And when you are travelling and eating, finding vegetarian sustenance is not just a matter of asking: “Do you have anything vegetarian?” Depending on where you are, “Do you have anything vegetarian?” has to be followed with an arsenal of inquiries, from “Can you make that without fish sauce?” to “Are the beans cooked in lard or oil?” </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/28/why-being-vegetarian-traveller-hard-to-swallow">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Havana rising: the millennials pushing Cuba forward</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/30/cuba-havana-music-art-restaurants-tech-tattoos</link>
      <description><p>Forget trying to see Cuba before it changes: the change is going on right now. From designers to tattooists, musicians to app designers, meet the young Habaneros changing the face of their city. Plus cool places to stay in the city</p><p>It’s difficult to figure out what is going to happen in this country,” Cuban designer Idania del Río tells me. We’re chatting in her first-floor studio in Old Havana, above the design shop she opened just over a year ago. Sporting a Superman T-shirt on which Lois Lane is pictured rescuing the superhero, del Río propels herself across the room on her office chair every time the phone rings. “Some people have had a mental switch. Young people are very energetic: they’re seeing what the future can be and are really enthusiastic about it, but they are focused on the present.”</p><p>Del Río is too modest to admit it, but her description of the energy building up in Havana also applies to her shop – it’s the first independent design outlet in Cuba – and to the growing number of independent, outward-looking people and projects springing up in the city.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/30/cuba-havana-music-art-restaurants-tech-tattoos">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>‘Birmingham is beautiful if you look at it in a certain way’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/29/steven-knight-peaky-blinders-birmingham</link>
      <description><p>For Peaky Blinders creator Steven Knight, Brum is undersold aesthetically and historically – something he wants to help rectify</p><p><strong>The story that made me want to write Peaky Blinders came from my dad. </strong>When he was about eight he had to deliver a note to the Sheldons, the real Peaky Blinders. He was terrified of them and had to run barefoot through the streets. When the door opened, smoke wafted out and there were nine men round a table, immaculately dressed – ties, shoes polished, hats, guns – and the table piled with money, but they were drinking beer out of jam jars, because they wouldn’t spend money on glasses or cups. The image of a little kid looking on made me want to write about that whole era.</p><p><strong>My mum and dad grew up in Small Heath in Birmingham in the 1920s.</strong> Mum was a runner for illegal bookmakers when she was nine or 10; they often used children, who aroused less suspicion. She used to walk down the street with a washing basket and people would wrap their bet – sixpence or whatever – in a piece of paper with the horse’s name and their code name on it, and drop it in the basket when she walked past, because there would be policemen watching.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/29/steven-knight-peaky-blinders-birmingham">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>10 of the best glamping sites in the UK</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/26/10-best-glamping-sites-camping-uk</link>
      <description><p>Camping purists may sneer but glamping is here to stay with hundreds of sites scattered across the UK. We pick 10 additions to Cool Camping’s new book, <a href="https://www.coolcamping.co.uk/books/8-glamping-getaways">Glamping Getaways</a><br></p><p>Two yurts and an octagonal “caban” (pictured above) accompany a handful of tent pitches at <a href="https://www.coolcamping.co.uk/campsites/uk/wales/snowdonia/gwynedd/100-graig-wen"><strong>Graig Wen</strong></a> on the banks of the Mawddach estuary. Each is furnished with Welsh blankets and wood burners, and windows in the cabin walls provide a 360-degree view of the pines beyond. It’s a short walk for the most dramatic river views, and you can cycle road-free all the way to Fairbourne beach, climb Snowdonia’s Cader Idris directly from the site, or drive the 10 minutes to Snowdon. <br>• <em>Yurts for two/five people from £100/£190 for two nights, caban (sleeps 2) from £160 for two nights midweek, more at weekends, 01341 250482</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/26/10-best-glamping-sites-camping-uk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Spain, swords and sorcery: how Tudela enchanted the Game of Thrones producers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/24/spain-swords-sorcery-tudela-game-of-thrones-location-season-six</link>
      <description><p>A key location in season six of GoT, Tudela, in northern Spain, has the perfect blend of drama, desert and ghoulish charm</p><p>It must be difficult being a Game of Thrones writer. Difficult to find gruesome new ways to maim and kill people. The show’s millions of fans aren’t going to be kept happy with routine beheadings and disembowelments, with a penectomy thrown in for fun. So what’s a writer to do once season six rolls round?</p><p>The first five series were filmed in some of Europe’s most spectacular locations, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2014/mar/09/iceland-film-road-trip-hollywood-of-the-north">from Iceland</a> and Croatia to Malta and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/apr/11/game-of-thrones-tourist-fans-northern-ireland-tv">Northern Ireland</a>, creating a tourist boom in many places as fans stalked Jon Snow and co. Perhaps that’s why the producers chose an area near the city of Tudela in the northern Spanish region of Navarra as one of the key new filming locations for the latest season – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/game-of-thrones">which starts on Monday</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/24/spain-swords-sorcery-tudela-game-of-thrones-location-season-six">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 jazz festivals in Europe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/20/top-10-jazz-festivals-europe-montreux-umbria-cork</link>
      <description><p>These summer festivals pay respect to artists old and new – and beyond jazz itself – at some stunning venues across Europe<br><br>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/feb/02/10-best-jazz-clubs-europe-paris-berlin-madrid-prague"><strong>10 of the best jazz clubs in Europe</strong></a></p><p><strong>24-27 June</strong><br><strong>Highlight</strong> Pat Metheny Quartet<br>Lviv is an architectural treasure, close to the Polish border, and many of its Habsburg, art nouveau and baroque buildings survived 20th-century wars relatively unscathed. This festival, established in 2011, has three stages hosting artists from all over Europe, as well as US stars such as Pat Metheny, Esperanza Spalding, Dianne Reeves and Branford Marsalis, who are joined by Cuban trumpet virtuoso Arturo Sandoval. Among the free highlights away from the main Eddie Rosner stage will be UK group Sons of Kemet and master percussionist Trilok Gurtu performing in the open air on beautiful Rynok Square.<br><strong>Accommodation options</strong> Among the best-located B&amp;Bs in the city is the 38-room <a href="http://modern-arthotel.com/en/hotel.html">Modern Art Hotel</a>, doubles from £28<br>• <em>Eddie Rosner stage gigs from £12, </em><a href="https://alfajazzfest.com/"><em>alfajazzfest.com</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/20/top-10-jazz-festivals-europe-montreux-umbria-cork">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Chernobyl, Ukraine: the nuclear option holiday</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/24/chernobyl-ukraine-the-nuclear-option-holiday</link>
      <description><p>Thirty years after reporting the nuclear meltdown, Kim Willsher returns to consider the new ‘disaster tourism’</p><p>Standing 100 yards from the husk of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/chernobyl-nuclear-disaster">Chernobyl</a>’s Reactor Number 4, the click-click-click of the Geiger counter becomes alarmingly insistent. One step closer and it is beeping and flashing. Our guide gives a reassuring smile. “It’s fine,” she says. But she knows we know she would say that.</p><p>Soon, we are back on the bus and driving away from the Vladimir Ilyich Lenin Power Station, better known as Chernobyl. When I first visited, two years after the world’s worst nuclear accident, it took weeks of negotiating with the Soviet authorities to gain access to the plant. Today, busloads of visitors arrive on an almost daily basis. For less than £100, the adventurous can take a one-day tour of the so-called “dead zone”, the contaminated 10km circle drawn around Chernobyl after the accident in the early hours of 26 April 1986.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/24/chernobyl-ukraine-the-nuclear-option-holiday">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Modernist living: let your mind wander at Alain de Botton's Life House</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/22/modernist-living-architecture-alain-de-botton-life-house-wales</link>
      <description><p>The latest house in the philosopher’s Living Architecture project is a minimalist space in Wales that offers an expansive – if expensive – escape from everyday life</p><p>The living room of <a href="http://www.living-architecture.co.uk/the-houses/LifeHouse/overview/">Tŷ Bywyd</a> fills me with awe and terror. Awe because the room is museum-huge, with pale timber beams and a wall of windows overlooking picture-book Welsh hills, with bouncing lambs. Terror because although the furnishings are minimalist, everything – from the marble-topped coffee table to the draped-glass floor lamps – looks exquisitely breakable.</p><p>As someone who sloshes mugs of tea and spreads sticky blue ink from broken biros, I’m more than capable of doing serious damage here on my own. But I’ve got my wrecking crew with me: seven-year-old twin boys whose energetic chasing game in the last place we stayed ended with me writing a cheque to replace a shattered table.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/22/modernist-living-architecture-alain-de-botton-life-house-wales">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Exploring the real Iran, with social media as your guide</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/19/exploring-iran-travels-facebook-instagram-couchsurfing</link>
      <description><p>Travelling independently, our writer relies on the advice and generosity of the young Iranians who are using social media to show foreign visitors the warm, fun and defiant reality of everyday life in their country</p><p>Being completely disconnected on holiday isn’t as romantic as some purist travellers may suggest. It might be fine if you plan to stay on a beach or spend your days snorkelling with dolphins, but if you have to navigate your way around a country, travelling without access to GPS-assisted maps, currency converters and email seems a silly restriction. Especially when travelling in a country like Iran. Here, the private and public spheres are two completely different worlds and access to social media can make the difference between merely learning about heritage through visits to historical sites and experiencing the everyday lives of modern Iranians.</p><p>It was how I came to be at a party in Tehran among a crowd of good-looking, fashionable millennials: men, women, gay, straight. The obligatory hijabs were left at the door. On the kitchen table, there were unmarked bottles of <em>aragh saghi</em> – literally, dog alcohol – a moonshine made from raisins. People were dancing, drinking, and discussing whether it was time to call a drug dealer.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/19/exploring-iran-travels-facebook-instagram-couchsurfing">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Pipe dreams: on the trail of Maigret’s Paris</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/17/on-the-trail-of-maigrets-paris-city-guide</link>
      <description><p>Tom Downey goes in search of the French capital’s landmarks – as patrolled by Georges Simenon’s French detective</p><p>By rights Le Bar du Caveau, on the Ile de la Cité’s Place Dauphine, one of the most picturesque squares in the very centre of the tourist’s Paris, should have been crammed with foreigners. Instead, at lunch hour, the only time it was open, it was filled with lawyers from the adjoining Palais de Justice who clearly hadn’t got to talk enough in court because they were now screaming their heads off.</p><p>I asked, politely and in French, if a female lawyer sitting to my left wanted to switch places with me so she could more easily converse with the man sitting to my right. “No,” she said and then continued to shout in my ear to communicate with her colleague. The perfectly creamy, soft-scrambled eggs piled on to crisp brown bread were partial consolation.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/17/on-the-trail-of-maigrets-paris-city-guide">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cold calling: a wild swimming adventure in the Lake District</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/10/wild-swimming-in-the-lake-district</link>
      <description><p>Richard Nelsson takes a unique opportunity to lose himself in England’s stunning watery wilderness on a swimming-and-hiking journey</p><p>Shivering, but on a cold-water high, we were all congratulating each other on a fine early morning swim across Windermere when Simon dropped the bombshell. “Guys, I’ve left my glasses by the jetty on the other side.”</p><p>Our plan – months in the making – to swim and hike across the southern Lake District was falling apart when we’d barely begun. Five of us were making the unsupported two-day trek, carrying and towing our gear across fell and forest, lake and tarn. Retrieving the glasses would take at least a couple of hours.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/10/wild-swimming-in-the-lake-district">Continue reading...</a></description>
