    <item>
      <title>10 of the best gardens … that you’ve probably never heard of</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/11/10-best-gardens-youve-probably-never-heard-of-uk-italy-japan</link>
      <description><p>Forget big names such as Kew and Versailles, these almost-secret gardens around the world are worth tracking down, for lovers of horticulture, sculpture – and the bizarre</p><p>This year marks the <a href="http://www.capabilitybrown.org/">300th anniversary</a> of the birth of English landscape gardener Lancelot “Capability” Brown, who created lakes, built hills and planted forests in the process of creating over 170 spectacular parks. Among his finest creations are Harewood in Leeds and Croome Park, Worcestershire (which has a wonderful <a href="http://www.croomewalledgardens.com/">secret walled garden</a>), but those with a particular interest in Brown’s work should make the effort to visit some of his lesser-known creations. One of these is Gatton Park in Surrey, a 240-hectare (600 acre) park on which Brown worked in the 1760s. He created a series of ponds, a serpentine and a lake with two islands, offering picture-perfect views of the house through the trees and woodland. Also at Gatton Park is a Japanese garden and a rock garden, both built in the early 1900s.<br>•<em> £4 entry, children free. Open to the public Feb-Oct on the first Sunday of each month, 1-5pm. Weekly tours take place Tues and Thurs at 2pm, £6. </em><a href="http://www.gattonpark.com/"><em>gattonpark.com</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/11/10-best-gardens-youve-probably-never-heard-of-uk-italy-japan">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Different strokes: wild swimming in Spain</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/10/wild-swimming-spain-madrid-barcelona-andalucia-galicia</link>
      <description><p>Forget the costas – mountain rivers and clear lakes offer the best escape from Spain’s summer heat. The authors of the new <a href="http://www.wildthingspublishing.com/product/wild-swimming-spain/">Wild Swimming Spain </a>choose favourite bathing spots within reach of the big cities</p><p><strong> </strong>Just over an hour from Madrid, the granite outcrops of La Pedriza, in the Cuenca Alta del Manzanares regional park, provide the backdrop to a wonderful wild swimming spot. These mountains are the backdrop for Ernest Hemingway’s For Whom the Bell Tolls, set during the Spanish Civil War. Today, the area is popular with hikers, climbers and wild swimmers.We expected to pay an entrance fee but the men in the hut at the gates smile and wave us through. We drive 5km up through pine forests beneath the imposing mountains to a small bar and car park by the Manzanares river.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/10/wild-swimming-spain-madrid-barcelona-andalucia-galicia">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Buenos Aires’ new cocktail bars look back to the future</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/07/buenos-aires-new-cocktail-bars</link>
      <description><p>Argentina’s capital has an honourable cocktail tradition, and today’s bartenders are tapping into the past to revive local drinks, albeit with a new twist</p><p>You get an interesting reaction if you tell people in Buenos Aires that you’re going for a cocktail at Los Galgos, a small corner bar on a busy street a few blocks from the city’s courthouses. They will either offer a knowing nod of approval or, if they remember it in its former incarnation, a look of incredulity.</p><p>As one of the city’s historic cafes, Los Galgos – with its 1930s wood panelling and tarnished mirrors – was part of a dying breed. One by one, from Cafe Richmond to Bar Británico, these old haunts have been shutting down. Cortado coffees and cheese-and-ham toasted sandwiches just don’t bring in enough income to cover the overheads any more.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/07/buenos-aires-new-cocktail-bars">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Off-season in Andalucía: escape the crowds and save money</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/05/andalucia-spain-off-season-holidays-corsica-portugal-italy</link>
      <description><p>Travelling out of season to sunny southern Spain can make for a superb short break, as our writer discovers when he explores Andalucía’s hill towns<br><strong>Plus: off-season breaks to Corsica, Portugal and Italy</strong></p><p>The roads were calm and uncluttered, minutes passed before another vehicle appeared. On the horizon the Sierra Nevada rolled along in the sunlight, still snow-capped and blue-hued in places. Outside the car was the countryside of rural Andalucía, with its olive and almond groves, and spaghetti western-like terrain. I drove the narrow, cobbled roads into Alhama de Granada’s main square, Plaza Constitucion, and parked with ease, ready to explore this small hill town with its Moorish quarter, the Iglesia del Carmen and dramatic views of Los Tajos (the gorge).</p><p>The joys of this out-of-season break extended beyond the uncongested roads. The temperature was a pleasant 20C, the sunshine was constant, other tourists were few and the pace of life had shifted down a couple of gears. Yet, I had not driven to the back of beyond to get here: around 45 minutes’ drive in a hire car from Málaga airport had taken me to my base, the town of Archidona. The capital of Málaga province during Moorish rule, it’s now a regular working town with a population of around 9,000 and a reassuringly light dash of tourism.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/05/andalucia-spain-off-season-holidays-corsica-portugal-italy">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Top 10 music festivals in Europe for 2016</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/04/top-10-music-festivals-summer-2016-europe</link>
      <description><p>When it comes to cool sounds in the summer sunshine, continental Europe is your playground. We pick the best (mostly) affordable parties from Iceland’s Secret Solstice to Croatia’s Love International</p><p>As the Croatian festival scene bidding farewell last summer to its founding father, the Garden Festival, which bowed out after 10 years of magic, it now falls to Love International to carry the torch. Run by the team behind Bristol’s <a href="http://lovesavestheday.org/">Love Saves the Day</a> (with the Garden’s Nick Colgan also involved), the festival takes place at the Garden Resort in Tisno, in a natural amphitheatre with a private bay for cooling dips. It also features the kind of line-up to generate heart-throbbing party moments, with some of the most discerning house and disco selectors around: Prosumer, Bicep, Horse Meat Disco … Just thinking about it is making us want to shoot confetti in the air and spill our drink hugging a stranger.<br>• 2<em>9 June-6 July, full week pass £120, </em><a href="http://loveinternationalfestival.com/"><em>loveinternationalfestival.com</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/04/top-10-music-festivals-summer-2016-europe">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>England’s 2,800-mile Coast Path to open in 2020</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/02/england-coast-path-2020-norfolk-walking-holidays</link>
      <description><p>When the England Coast Path opens four years from now, it will cover the country’s entire seashore and be one of the world’s longest walking routes. Alan Franks walks a 25-mile stretch in Norfolk</p><p>For a small country like Britain, the idea of claiming one of the longest footpaths in the world sounds a little ambitious. But that’s what we’re up to with the creation of the <a href="http://www.nationaltrail.co.uk/england-coast-path">England Coast Path</a>, and the proposed completion date of 2020 is not too far away. The route will go all the way round the English coast, and a quick look at the map of this island nation, with its countless inlets, estuaries and jagged bits, shows that the projected total length of 2,795 miles is not as outlandish as it sounds.</p><p>It’s already possible to walk round the whole of the south-west peninsula, from Minehead in Somerset to Poole in Dorset, on the 630-mile <a href="http://www.southwestcoastpath.org.uk/">South West Coast Path</a>. This accounts for roughly a quarter of that target. There are also footpaths along substantial stretches of the coasts of Sussex, Kent, Essex, Lincolnshire and Northumbria.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/02/england-coast-path-2020-norfolk-walking-holidays">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/norfolk">Norfolk holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/walkingholidays">Walking holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/england">England holidays</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/uk">United Kingdom holidays</category>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 Barcelona walking tours</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/31/top-10-barcelona-walking-tours-catalonia-spain</link>
      <description><p>Gaze at graffiti, try the city’s best food or take a tour led by architects, photographers or even the homeless … Barcelona has a guided walk for everyone</p><p>A guided walk is the quick and easy way to learn lots about a place but at €10-€20pp the cost can soon rack up, particularly for a family. Guiding yourself keeps the price down and lets you choose your own pace. The Ruta del Modernisme winds through the city linking more than 100 examples of Catalonia’s famed take on art nouveau. You could be cheap and read descriptions of buildings from the ruta’s rather clunky website, but the accompanying guidebook is only €12 and gets you a discounted entry to many sights. All the biggies, such as Gaudí’s Sagrada Família and the Palau de la Música Catalana by Lluís Domènech i Montaner are on the ruta but you can search out the work of lesser-known architects, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2013/jun/03/jujol-architecture-tour-barcelona-catalonia-gaudi">such as my favourite, Josep Maria Jujol</a>.<br>• <a href="http://rutadelmodernisme.com/"><em>rutadelmodernisme.com</em></a><em>, guidebook available from </em><a href="http://www.mmbcn.cat/"><em>Museu del Modernisme de Barcelona</em></a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/31/top-10-barcelona-walking-tours-catalonia-spain">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Notes from Ethiopia: the jazz revival in Addis Ababa</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/01/jazz-revival-addis-ababa-ethiopia-ethio-jazz</link>
      <description><p>A hypnotic mix of musical styles, Ethio-jazz has a fascinating history and is enjoying a comeback at venues across the city – and it’s not just names from the past who are setting the tempo</p><p>I’m submerged in a heaving, sweaty mass of bodies, all singing, dancing, clapping along to the mesmeric crooning of Alemayehu Eshete – the man known as the Ethiopian Elvis. It’s Saturday night and I’m sharing limited oxygen with Addis Ababa’s great and good at <a href="https://www.facebook.com/MamasKitchenAddisAbaba">Mama’s Kitchen</a>, a wood-and-glass bar on the fourth floor of an innocuous shopping mall near Bole airport. Eshete, a shining star of the 1960s Ethiopian music scene, conducts the revelry in local Amharic tones as his band deliver a hypnotic mix of funky jazz, rockabilly and the swinging scales of traditional Ethiopian folk. This is <a draggable="true" href="http://theculturetrip.com/africa/ethiopia/articles/ethio-jazz-the-amazing-story-of-ethiopian-jazz-from-london-to-addis/">Ethio-jazz</a>.</p><p>A fusion of the eerie rhythms of ancient Ethiopian tribal music with the soulful undertones of jazz and the funky bounce of Afrobeat, Ethio-jazz had its heyday in the 1950s and 60s but in recent years has been making a slow but unmistakable comeback in the country’s capital.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/apr/01/jazz-revival-addis-ababa-ethiopia-ethio-jazz">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>10 of the most inspiring contemporary female adventurers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/30/top-10-inspiring-contemporary-uk-female-adventurers</link>
      <description><p>Following our article on <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/08/top-10-inspiring-female-travel-adventurers"><strong>female adventurers of the past</strong></a>, we’re bringing things up to date with a look at the explorers making their mark today and inspiring others to get out and blaze a trail</p><p>Journalist Nellie Bly jumped off the page at me as I was researching Victorian female travellers. The more I got to know her, the more I was intrigued by this fearless character who wouldn’t take no for an answer. Her crusades in print brought reforms in women’s asylums, orphanages, sweatshops and prisons.</p><p>The story that brought Bly the most acclaim was circling the globe in 72 days in 1890, beating the fictitious record in Jules Verne’s Around the World in 80 Days. One hundred and twenty five years later, I followed in her footsteps.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/30/top-10-inspiring-contemporary-uk-female-adventurers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>10 of the best European cities for art nouveau</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/29/10-best-art-nouveau-cities-europe-prague-budapest-glasgow</link>
      <description><p>Art nouveau swept across Europe around the turn of the 20th century and was embraced by architects, graphic and interior designers and artists. Here are the best cities in Europe to get a flavour of its most impressive buildings</p><p>Art nouveau was the curvilinear, nature-inspired style that dominated everything from jewellery to architecture at the start of the 20th century. As it spread throughout Europe and across the Atlantic it followed two main strands: the curvy, whiplash decoration that flowed out of Paris-Brussels and the more linear, geometric style seen in Vienna and Glasgow. East European centres such as Prague, Riga and Budapest merged art nouveau with their own local traditions and the outstanding buildings of the era are found in those cities. By 1915, the craze for art nouveau had been crushed by the advent of the first world war and the arrival of a new style, art deco.</p><p>Over the last 100 years the demolition of art nouveau structures has been ruthless. French architect Hector Guimard’s innovative Parisian concert hall was pulled down as early as 1905 and only three of his roofed entrances to the Paris metro remain. While Barcelona, Vienna, Munich and Subotica claim stunning yet isolated art nouveau buildings, other cities have managed to preserve the style as part of their dominant architectural heritage.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/29/10-best-art-nouveau-cities-europe-prague-budapest-glasgow">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Inside the world's largest cruise ship, Harmony of the Seas</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/13/inside-the-worlds-largest-cruise-ship-harmony-of-the-seas</link>
      <description><p>The giant vessel, which features a 1,400-seat theatre, a park with 12,000 plant species and a 10-storey water slide, will house 8,500 passengers and crew </p><p>The world’s biggest-ever cruise ship, the 120,000-tonne Harmony of the Seas, has opened its doors to reveal a vast floating town as it was handed over by a French shipyard to its American owners.</p><p>At 66 metres (217ft), it is the widest cruise ship ever built, while its 362m length makes it 50 metres longer than the height of the Eiffel Tower.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/13/inside-the-worlds-largest-cruise-ship-harmony-of-the-seas">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I would drive 500 miles: Scotland’s new North Coast 500 route</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/aug/23/scotland-north-coast-500-road-trip</link>
      <description><p>The new North Coast 500 road trip is Scotland’s answer to America’s Route 66. Our writer gets her kicks from wild beaches, high passes and spooky ruins</p><p>The term “road trip” has the roar of a Chevrolet, the lure of never-ending Californian freeways, and nuances of the wild freedom of Beat writer Jack Kerouac. But here we were in the Highlands, about to embark on the recently launched North Coast 500, a new coastal route billed as Scotland’s answer to the US Route 66.</p><p>It forms a loop around the whole northern tip of Scotland, from Inverness, close to our home, to John O’Groats in the north-east, along the stark sea of the north to Durness, then down the convoluted west coast before turning inland at the Applecross peninsula. The itinerary was designed by the <a href="http://www.northhighlandinitiative.co.uk/">North Highland Initiative</a>, a non-profit organisation established by Prince Charles to spread the love across less-visited parts of the northern Highlands.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/aug/23/scotland-north-coast-500-road-trip">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>10 of the best European islands … that you’ve probably never heard of</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/may/11/10-best-european-islands-holidays-greece-italy-france-spain</link>
      <description><p>Explore Europe’s lesser-known islands and enjoy a leisurely break where walking, watersports and doing nothing at all are the order of the day</p><p>A far cry from Norway’s jagged western fjord-filled coastline, the Lyngør Islands offer Baltic calm rather than wild Atlantic. Base yourself on the islands of Sandøya or Borøya (where you can park your car) and use the ferries to get around. If ferries are too mainstream, Norwegians rave about kayaking between these tiny islands, so expect to see lots of brightly coloured boats being hefted around by visitors. Kayak rental is available in Tvedestrand, the town at the head of the fjord. <a href="http://www.arendal.com/en/Sights/Lyngor/">Lyngør Island</a> can only be reached by boat: there are no cars, and the main village consists of weathered clapboard wooden houses.<br><strong>Stay</strong> The <a href="http://www.villas.com/en-gb/norway/aust-agder/tvedestrand/holiday-home-tvedestrand-58.html?ac_pageview_id=e37d5d93f4fc0069&amp;ac_position=0&amp;ac_suggestion_list_length=1&amp;aid=387646&amp;checkin_monthday=22&amp;checkin_year_month=2015-9&amp;checkout_monthday=23&amp;checkout_year_month=2015-9&amp;dcid=4&amp;group_adults=2&amp;group_children=0&amp;label=gog235jc-index-XX-XX-XX-nobrand-gb-com-L%3Aen-O%3Aunk-B%3Aunk-N%3Ayes-S%3Avi&amp;no_rooms=1&amp;sb_predefined_group_options_value=3&amp;si=ai%2Cco%2Cci%2Cre%2Cdi&amp;sid=c4e133fd607fe5c0209db0d6fda90359&amp;src=index&amp;ss=Holiday%20home%20Tvedestrand%2058%2C%20Tvedestrand%2C%20Aust-Agder%2C%20Norway&amp;ss_raw=Tvedestrand%2058&amp;">Tvedestrand 58 holiday house</a> on the island of Boroya, which sleeps up to six, costs from £455 for seven nights.<br><strong>Getting there</strong> <a href="http://www.norwegian.com/uk/?gclid=Cj0KEQjwmqyqBRC7zKnO_f6iodcBEiQA9T996JauR765a_e_p-4x4LVHmthCbPmzxNYZVRWAZV1NGdsaAheM8P8HAQ&amp;gclsrc=aw.ds">Norwegian</a> airlines flies to Oslo from £40 return; it’s then a two-hour drive south.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/may/11/10-best-european-islands-holidays-greece-italy-france-spain">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>School's out and summer camps are in as parents try to beat holiday boredom</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2013/jul/26/summer-camps-school-holidays</link>
      <description>From coding to Mandarin lessons to 'princess preparation', there's an array of options – for those who can afford it<br /><br /><a href="http://www.guardian.co.uk/education/2013/jul/26/school-holidays-your-tips-open-thread" title="">Share your summer holiday tips</a><br /><a href="http://www.guardian.co.uk/travel/travel+education/school-holidays" title="">More ideas for keeping your children entertained this summer</a><p>The summer camp is often seen as a distinctly American institution, conjuring images of fresh-faced youths bombing along zip wires or camping under the stars. But British parents are increasingly relying on a range of eclectic summer camps in an attempt to fend off children's boredom until September.</p><p>While sport and art-based camps have been around for decades, a new breed of summer camps – offering everything from <a href="http://www.xkeys.co.uk/residential-camp/" title="">scuba diving</a> to <a href="http://www.techcamp.org.uk/" title="">coding classes</a> – are gaining traction in the UK as parents look to equip their offspring with skills for the new term.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2013/jul/26/summer-camps-school-holidays">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>California's top 10 beach hotels and places to stay on a budget</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2012/apr/11/california-top-10-budget-beach-hotels</link>
      <description>Few places are as synonymous with the beach as California, but staying on it can be expensive. So here's our pick of 10 affordable and brilliantly located beach pads, from campsites and cabins to budget inns<p>These bohemian, higgledy-piggledy beach cottages sit in the heart of Crystal Cove State Park's 3½ miles of winding white-sand coastline. They were built in the 30s and 40s and have been lovingly restored with vintage seaside furniture and period details. Each cottage is either on the beach or looking down on it from a bluff top, connected by winding wooden pathways and wind beaten painted fences. A cute nearby cafe, <a href="http://www.thebeachcombercafe.com/_crystalcove/index.aspx" title="">The Beachcomber</a>, serves breakfast, lunch and dinner and a takeaway Shake Shack serves burgers, fries and milkshakes (which is useful, because the cottages don't have ovens).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2012/apr/11/california-top-10-budget-beach-hotels">Continue reading...</a></description>
